item.title: Marius "Curt" Page Jr.
item.content:encoded:
Marius “Curt” Page Jr, 85, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully on Friday, Dec. 16, 2016 with his loving family by his side. Curt was born in Baraboo on March 26, 1931 the son of Marius Curt Page Sr. and Kathryn Manning. He was a 1949 graduate of Baraboo High School and attended the University of Wisconsin-Madison receiving a Bachelors degree in Political Science in 1953, and a Law Degree in 1956. Curt was most known for the family business at the Baraboo News Republic where he was chief editor and general manager. In addition, he was an attorney at law as well as a CPA doing numerous tax returns for family and friends. Prior to retirement, he was a Walmart greeter who provided a cheerful smile to every customer who entered the store. On Sept. 22, 1962 he was united in marriage to Helen Hammer at St. Matthews Catholic Church in Shullsburg. From this union they were blessed with two children, Michael and Robin. Curt was very active in the community and was a member of several organizations which included the Knights of Columbus, Baraboo Optimist Club, Baraboo Elks Lodge No. 688, and the Baraboo Masonic Lodge #34 F & AM (Master Mason, 1983). In addition, he was a member of St. Joseph Catholic Church and served as long-time treasurer at Trinity Episcopal Church in Baraboo. Curt enjoyed chatting with friends about his love for sports. He had an encyclopedia knowledge of Baraboo athletics, the Wisconsin Badgers and the Green Bay Packers. He was also known as an avid animal lover and many dogs and cats were always welcomed and became part of the family. They were never turned away and there was always room for one more. Curt was known by many to be kind, generous, positive and a remarkable human being. He was a pillar in our community that affected many lives and his legacy will be long remembered. Survivors include his wife, Helen of 54 years; son, Michael (Becky) Page of Belvidere, Illinois; daughter, Robin (Kevin) Korneff of Richland Center; six grandchildren, Amanda (Tom) Alderson, Margaret (Steven) Rovik, Matthew Otto, Cory, Joshua and Haleigh Page; four great-grandchildren, Asher, Tyler, Jase and William. Also surviving is a brother-in-law, Joseph Kiser; four sisters-in-laws, Patricia (Eugene) Mullen, Donna Schardt, Kay (Mike) Gile and Joan (Tom) Sheehan; and many nieces and nephews. In addition to his parents, Curt was preceded in death by a sister, Pamela Page Kiser; parent in-law, Elmer and Margaret Hammer; and a brother-in-law, Gerald Schardt. A Memorial Mass will be held at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, Dec. 21, 2016 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 a.m. until time of Mass. Private family inurnment will take place in the spring. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the Sauk County Humane Society. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family would like to give a special thank you to the caregivers at Oak Park Place, Agrace Hospice and Dr. Daniel Trotter for the compassionate care provided to Curt.

item.title: Janet C. Bjornsen
item.content:encoded:
Janet C. Bjornsen, 92, of Baraboo, passed away on Thursday, Dec. 1, 2016 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center after a short illness. Janet was born in Milwaukee on Feb. 10, 1924, the daughter of August and Olive Church. At age 12, Janet and her three brothers moved to Baraboo. She joined the United States Navy after high school as a Hospital Corpsman and was stationed in Portsmouth, Virginia. After her service to our country, Janet took advantage of the GI Bill and attended UW Madison, graduating with a bachelor degree in social work. Janet married Martin J. Bjornsen on July 15, 1950 and remained in Baraboo raising their two children. She enjoyed working as a paralegal for various attorneys throughout her career and would remain life-long friends with her first “boss” James Karch. Janet is survived by her children, Eric (Susan) Bjornsen and Karen (Jim) Sanner; two grandchildren, Jamie Sanner and Eric (Brianna) Sanner; and three wonderful great-grandchildren, Journey, Alexis and James. Janet was preceded in death by her husband, Martin; and her three brothers. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, Dec. 6, 2016 at the First Presbyterian Church, Baraboo, with Pastor Lisa Taylor officiating. Visitation will take place one hour prior to the service. Interment will be held in Walnut Hill Cemetery with military rites provided by the Baraboo Veterans Honor Guard. In lieu of flowers, memorials can be made to The Sons of Norway-Vakkertland Lodge, an organization that was important to both Janet and Martin. Condolences should be mailed to 1033 5th Street, Baraboo, WI. 53913. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family wishes to thank the wonderful and compassionate staff at Meadow Lane Assisted Living Facility and the great staff that cared for her while she was in the St. Clare Meadows Care Center.

item.title: Irene Ann Breneman
item.content:encoded:
Irene Ann Breneman, 85, of Baraboo, passed away on Sunday, Nov. 27, 2016 at her residence with her loving family by her side. Irene was born on Feb. 5, 1931 in Portage, the daughter of Edwin and Helen (Lockwood) Breneman. She was a 1949 graduate of Pardeeville High School and moved to Milwaukee where she lived for over 40 years. While in Milwaukee, she worked for Liberty Mutual Insurance Company as a mail clerk. She retired after 38 years and moved to Baraboo to be with her family. In her spare time she enjoyed gardening, sewing, crocheting and collecting crafts. Irene is survived by her brother, Kenneth (Ruth) Breneman of Baraboo; nieces and nephews, David, Vicky (Joe), Tammy (Richard) and Carl Breneman, and Teahanna (Charles) Olson; great-nieces and great-nephews, Kelsie (Stephen) Breneman, Cody (Lindsey) and Colton Holsaple, Kailee and Ciera Breneman, Alexander Olson; great-nieces, Trinidy and Lileyanne Fleming; great-great nephew, Julian Breneman; great-great-niece, Arianna Holsaple; and special friends, Kris, Judy, Cheryl, Audrey, Jody, Kathy, Jack and Carol. In addition to her parents, Irene was preceded in death by a sister, Shirley; and several aunts, uncles and other relatives. Memorial Services will be held at 11 a.m. on Friday, Dec. 2, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo, with Pastor Amos Vande Hei officiating. Visitation will be from 10 a.m. until the time of service. The family would like to thank Dr. Stuart Hannah and the staff at Home Health United Hospice for the care given to Irene. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

Linda was born on March 10, 1949 in Baraboo, the daughter of Robert and Jeanette (Dahlke) Rosenbaum. She was married to Kenneth Wilcox in Baraboo. Linda enjoyed music, nature, going shopping and spending time with her family and friends. Survivors include her husband, Kenneth; her brothers and sisters, Bob (Rita) Rosenbaum, Charlotte Ribbke, Robin (Philip) Zimmerman, Gerry (Kathy) Rosenbaum, Mark (Jeanie) Rosenbaum; and several nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. item.title: Dorothy Jean Hamer
item.content:encoded:
Dorothy Jean Hamer, 91, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully on Wednesday, Nov. 9, 2016 at St. Clare Hospice House with her loving family by her side. Dorothy was born on April 22, 1925 in Baraboo, the daughter of Harry and Velma (Buss) McWilliams. On December 29, 1971 she was united in marriage to Harvard Hamer in La Valle. He preceded her in death on Dec. 15, 1999. Dorothy was employed at Flambeau Plastics and Servo Instrument Corp. before her retirement. In her spare time, she enjoyed reading, knitting, crossword puzzles, and visiting with family and friends. She will be dearly missed by her family but will always be remembered for her kindness and motherly love. Survivors include her three children, Judy McDuffie of Krum, Texas, Bill Zimmerman of Baraboo, and Kathy Wilson of Baraboo; six grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren, one great-great grandchild, and several nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. In addition to her parents and husband, Dorothy was preceded in death by a grandson, Richie McDuffie; and a brother, Jim. Memorial services will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, Nov. 15, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo, with Pastor Jesse Stevens officiating. Visitation will take place from 10 a.m. until time of service. Inurnment will be held in Greenwood Cemetery, Kingston Township, following the memorial service. The family would like to thank the staff at St. Clare Hospice House for the personal care given to Dorothy during her stay, and Rachel Heinzman at the ADRC of Sauk County for the guidance given to the family. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Deloris Mae Owsley
item.content:encoded:
Oxford - Deloris Mae Owsley, 83, of Oxford, passed away on Tuesday, Oct. 4, 2016 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center in Baraboo. Deloris was born on Dec. 2, 1932 in West Frankfort, Illinois, the daughter of William and Nina (Wilson) Showmaker. In 1950, she married Bertie “Burt” Owsley in Mississippi. He preceded her in death in June 19, 1982. Deloris was employed as a supervisor for Lee Ward Company in Elgin, Illinios for over 23 years. After her retirement, she moved to the Oxford area to be with her son whom she loved dearly. Survivors include her son, Charles “Chuck” (Peggy) Pietrantoni of Oxford; two brothers, Donald Showmaker of Elburn, Illinois and William “Billy” (Mary) Showmaker of Arizona; a sister, Mary Jane Risley of Elkton, Kentucky; and several nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. In addition to her husband and parents, Deloris was preceded in death by a sister, Ruby Ann Washau. Graveside services will take place at 2 p.m. on Friday, Oct. 7, 2016 in Denning Cemetery, Orient, Illinois. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Frank Randolph Marshall III
item.content:encoded:
Frank Randolph Marshall III, 86, of Baraboo, joined his Lord on Saturday, Sept. 24, 2016. Frank was born on Jan. 26, 1930 in Chicago, Illinois, to Louise (Keller) and Frank R. Marshall Jr. At age six, Frank moved to Oshkosh to live with his uncle, George and aunt, Rhea. He was the child they never had and they became the grandparents to his children. As a young man, Frank spent his summers playing tennis, football and helping his uncle in the butcher shop. He attended UW Oshkosh and transferred to UW Madison and graduated in 1954 with a BS degree in Economics. While at UW Madison, he played on the varsity tennis team. In 1970, he received a MS degree from UW Whitewater to teach Special Education. Frank taught in the Oregon, Richland Center and Baraboo school districts at the high school level. He loved his students and saw the need for them to have breakfast, so he provided toast and peanut butter. Frank was active in the communities where he lived and was president of the Sauk Prairie Optimist Club, member of the Baraboo Optimist Club serving on its board of directors, served three terms as Lt. Governor for the Optimist SWISS District, and raised over ten thousand dollars selling clown noses for childhood cancer research. Frank served 10 years on the Commission on Aging board of directors, drove for meals-on-wheels, and chauffeured those who needed transportation. Frank felt reading was the backbone of a child’s education and volunteered as a reading instructor at St. Joseph Catholic School in Baraboo, St. Aloysius in Sauk City and helped at the Kid’s Ranch. For over 35 years, Frank volunteered at nursing homes where ever he lived, and did church services at St. Clare Meadows Care Center for over 14 years with the help of his wife, Linda. Frank loved the Lord, and was called to do His work in many ways. He belonged to numerous men’s bible studies in his life which he dearly loved. In 1996, God called on Frank to do a bible study with the inmates at the Sauk County jail. So at age 76, Frank studied to become a minister to meet the qualification to do so. Frank was an avid sports fan of the Wisconsin Badgers and Green Bay Packers. He really looked forward to fall, as it meant the football season was approaching. Frank passed away during the Badger game and would have been very happy the won. Frank is survived by his first wife, Joanne Marshall (Teteak) of Florida, and their children, Paul (Michelle) of Anchorage, Alaska, and Kinberlee (Dan) McCrea of Whitewater; his second wife, Linda Marshall (Wolff) of Baraboo, and became a father to Charles (Kathryan) Listello of Greely, Colorado, and Michael Listello of Hove, England; five blessed grandchildren, Matt and Peter of Whitewater, Twyla of Greely, Colorado, and Alexandria and John of Hove, England. In addition, he leaves behind a large family of in-laws, friends and best friend and sports buddy, Frank Krom of Chicago, Illinois. He was preceded in death by his only sister, Joan; his favorite niece, Darcy; his aunt, Rhea and uncle, George; and his parents. A celebration of Frank’s life will take place at 11 a.m. on Saturday, Oct. 8, 2016 at Walnut Hill Bible Church, 1900 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor David Hutchens officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 a.m. until time of service. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to, the reading program for children, c/o Kids Ranch, P.O. Box 219, Baraboo, or your local Optimist Club for Childhood Cancer Campaign. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. Linda would like to thank all the people who supported her during Frank’s illness. She feels blessed to have her family support of Tom (Judy) Wolff and Kay Barbian of Prairie du Sac, Paul Wolff of Baraboo, Lindley Wolff of Waunakee, and her niece, Denise Earp of Merrimac, who would come running if she needed help. Also, the support from members of Walnut Hill Bible Church, Dr. Danny Sessler and the nurses and volunteers for Home Health United Hospice for whom made it possible to care for Frank at home until the day he went to see His Heavenly Father.

item.title: Thomas "Tom" F. Mcintyre
item.content:encoded:
Thomas “Tom” F. McIntyre, 82, of Baraboo, passed away on Friday, Sept. 23, 2016 at St. Mary’s Hospital in Madison. Tom was born in Baraboo on Feb. 17, 1934, the son of William L. and Rachel H. (Knoop) McIntyre. He grew-up in North Freedom and graduated 8th grade from St. Joseph Parochial School in 1948, and from Baraboo High School in 1952. He was drafted into the United States Army where he served his country from November of 1958 until November of 1964 and was honorably discharged from the Army Reserve. Tom was employed as a salesman at Vodak Radio and TV for over 35 years until his retirement. In his spare time, he did volunteer work at St. Clare Meadows Care Center and was a life-long member of St. Joseph Catholic Church in Baraboo. Survivors include his brother, William “Mick” (Carol) McIntyre of Baraboo; several cousins; and many friends and neighbors from the Donahue Apartments where he had lived for the past 18 years. He was preceded in death by his parents. A funeral Mass will be held on Thursday, Sept. 29, 2016 at 11 a.m. at St. Joseph Catholic Church, Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 a.m. until time of Mass. Interment will take place in Oak Hill Cemetery in North Freedom with military rites provided by the North Freedom American Legion Post 172. Memorials in memory of Tom may be given to the St. Clare Hospice House in Baraboo. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: David John Etzwiler
item.content:encoded:
David John Etzwiler, 75, of Baraboo, died at home surrounded by his family, after a short but losing battle with cancer. David was born on Jan. 15, 1941 in Mansfield, Ohio, the youngest of three sons of Claude and Germaine Etzwiler. He graduated from St. Peter’s School in Mansfield, and went on to St. Joseph’s College, Rensselaer, Indiana, for a BS in Math. He spent a year as a Fulbright scholar in Tuebingen, Germany, then returned to the states to study at UW-Madison for an MS in Math. There he met Nijole Semenas, for whom he was the love of her life. They married on Dec. 26, 1964, and together went into the Peace Corps in Brazil. On returning home, they settled in Wisconsin and raised three boys. He taught in Hamburg, Germany for two years and took every opportunity to introduce the art and culture of Europe to his family. David began working at UWC-Baraboo/Sauk County in 1977, and retired from there in 2003, but continued as a volunteer tutor and teacher for many years. He was a member of the Sauk County Historical Society, the Al Ringling Friends, AMATYC (American Mathematical Association of Two-Year Colleges), and Madison Vilnius Sister Cities, and active in the Baraboo Community Scholarship Corporation, Zaibas Lithuanian Dancers, and the St. Joseph Church Choir. David was an adventurous traveler, loved cruises, train rides, and biking in Germany as well as Sauk County. David was preceded in death by his parents and parents-in-law. He is survived by his wife of 52 years, Nijole Etzwiler; sons, Chris (Angie) Etzwiler of Des Plaines, Illinois, Peter (Elise) Etzweiler, and Michael Etzwiler (Ken Kealiher) of Baraboo; beloved grandchildren, Andrew and Zoe Etzweiler and Eric and Valerie Etzwiler; brothers, Tom (Ruth) Etzwiler and James P. Martin; and other relatives and friends. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, Sept. 21, 2016 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 a.m. until time of Mass. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the UWC-Baraboo/Sauk County, http://baraboo.uwc.edu/support/support-uw-bsc or the Baraboo Community Scholarship Corporation, http://barabooscholarships.com/ The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family thanks St. Clare Hospital for its loving care of David, and Home Health United Hospice Care for its support.

item.title: Dale H. Hinz
item.content:encoded:
Dale H. Hinz, 69, of Baraboo, passed away after a courageous battle with cancer on Thursday, Sept. 15, 2016 at his residence with his loving family by his side. Dale was born on Dec. 27, 1946 in Baraboo, the son of Wilbur and Norma (Harpold) Hinz. He attended Reedsburg High School and enlisted in the United States Army and was honorably discharged in January of 1970. Dale was united in marriage to Joann Beckwith on Oct. 21, 1967 at St. Paul’s Lutheran church in Baraboo. Dale was employed as a truck driver and worked for several local companies which included; Korth, Hankscraft, Penda-Trienda and Skinner. He then ventured out on his own as an independent owner-operator of his own semi. In his spare time, Dale enjoyed golfing, fishing and spending time with the grandchildren. His greatest joy in his life was supporting his grandchildren and their accomplishments in hockey and golf. In addition, Dale was a member of St. Paul’s Lutheran Church in Baraboo. Survivors include his wife of 49 years, Joann of Baraboo; four sons, Lance Hinz, Cory (Gail) Hinz, Matthew Hinz and Ryan (Katie Murphy) Hinz; three grandchildren, Dawson, Dane and Gavin; three brothers, Tom (Cheryl) Hinz, Gary (Linda) Hinz and Rex (Judy) Hinz; and other nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by his parents. Memorial services will take place at 3 p.m. on Tuesday, Sept. 20, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo, with Pastor Amos Vande Hei officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home from 1 p.m. until time of services. Inurnment will take place in Oak Hill Cemetery in North Freedom. The family would like to thank the Doctors, staff and members of Home Health United for the wonderful care given to Dale. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Daisy Joan Kelly
item.content:encoded:
Daisy Joan Kelly, 90, of Baraboo, passed away on Saturday, Sept. 3, 2016 at her residence. Daisy was born on Dec. 15, 1925 in Birmingham England, the daughter of Ernest Edward and Daisy May (Smith) Prince. On May 12, 1945, she married Virgil Blain Kelly in Birmingham, England. He preceded her in death on May 8, 1995. She was a loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother who lived for family. Daisy enjoyed knitting and crocheting along with fishing at the cottage in Nekoosa. Survivors include her son, Michael of Baraboo; three grandchildren, Michael (Angela) Kelly of Madison, Connie Kelly of Phoenix, Arizona, Jeremy Kelly of Merrimac; three great-grandchildren, John Kelly of Milwaukee, Casey Kelly of Madison, Gage Kelly of Merrimac; a sister, Elizabeth Straka of Madison; daughter-in-law, Linda Kelly of Merrimac; and other relatives and friends. In addition to her husband and parents, Daisy was preceded in death by four siblings. A celebration of Daisy’s life will take place at River Memorial Park, Merrimac, on Sunday, Sept. 11, 2016 from 1 p.m. until 4 p.m. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Celia E. Ford
item.content:encoded:
Celia E. Ford, 94, of Baraboo, passed away on Thursday, Sept. 1, 2016 at Maplewood Nursing Home of Sauk City. Celia was born on Oct. 8, 1921 in Chicago, Illinois, the daughter of John and Lillian (Skalska) Murawski. On June 8, 1940, Celia married Edward Piotrowski at Old Saint Stanislaus Church in Chicago. Together, they had a son named James. Edward passed away in January of 1958 and Celia then married Charles Ford on Aug. 3, 1968, in Chicago. He preceded her in death on July 26, 1993. While living in Chicago, Celia worked at Gold Blatz Department store and Pharmaceutical Company. After the passing of Charles, she moved to Baraboo to live with her son, Jim. He preceded her in death in 1995. Celia was a faithful and devoted friend who always thought positive and was very proud of her polish heritage. She was a member of St. Joseph Catholic Church and will be dearly missed. Survivors include her grandchildren, Christine Noone, Denise, Mitchell and Carl Piotrowski; two great- grandchildren, Nicholas and Brian; two nephews, Ronald and Bob Kurek; and other relatives and friends. In addition to her husbands, parents and son, Celia was preceded in death by a sister, Jeanette Kurek in 1990. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, Sept. 6, 2016 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 am until time of Mass. Burial will take place in St. Joseph Cemetery. Memorials in memory of Celia may be given to the church. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Beverly Jane Raymond
item.content:encoded:
Beverly J. Raymond, 65, of Baraboo, passed away suddenly but peacefully at her home on Aug. 25, 2016. Beverly was born on Feb. 28, 1951 in Williston, North Dakota, to Betty and Douglas Amsbaugh. She grew-up in North Dakota and South Dakota and eventually made her home in Baraboo. She was an educator in the Baraboo and Sauk County school systems for many years and had recently retired. She loved working in her yard and tending her plants. She also enjoyed cooking and baking cakes. Beverly is survived by her son, James of Baraboo; her mother, Betty Amsbaugh of Rapid City, South Dakota; and her brother, James Amsbaugh of King George, Virginia. She was preceded in death by her father, Douglas; a sister, Elaine; and a brother, Dale. Graveside services will be held at 2 p.m. on Wednesday, Sept. 21, 2016 at St. Joseph Cemetery in Baraboo with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. The Family requests that expressions of sympathy, condolences or memorials be sent in care of J. Amsbaugh, 15583 Fleming St., King George, VA 22485. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Carol Ann "Annie" Randall
item.content:encoded:
Carol Ann Randall, 69, of Baraboo, known to family and friends as “Annie”, passed away on Thursday, Aug. 25, 2016. Born in Lodi on May 21, 1947 to Alvin and Anna (Kordik) Eckardt, Annie graduated with a music major from the University of Wisconsin-Madison and founded Devilwood Morgan Farm in 1979. In 1998 Annie opened the Village Booksmith, a used and rare edition bookstore in Baraboo. Her store became a creative outlet and center for the community. She hosted holiday potlucks, rode in area parades, started a women’s sextet, (The Cheddar Chicks), organized carolers around the Square and enhanced the community with her talent and good will. Annie was a skilled equestrian, showing, training, and breeding Morgan horses, announcing and judging horse shows throughout the area. She promoted competitive carriage driving nationally and has served in many offices of The Wisconsin Morgan Horse Club. Annie is survived by her partner, Walter Leutenegger; his son, Maurice; her loving stepchildren, Debra (Lee) Bumbicka, Paul Randall, Steve (Karla) Randall, Penny Randall; and grandchildren, Kym, Stuart, Brian, Dan, Mikey, Katie; and her golden retriever, Nellie. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, Aug. 31, 2016 at the First Congregational United Church of Christ, 131 6th Ave., Baraboo, with Pastor Douglas Fauth officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 9 a.m. until time of service. Burial will take place in St. Patrick Cemetery in Lodi at 1:30 p.m. In addition, a Celebration of Annie’s Life and potluck dinner will take place at the Red Oak Shelter on the South Shore of Devil’s Lake State Park, starting at 5 p.m. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to; the Wisconsin Morgan Horse Club or the Greater Sauk County Community Foundation. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Russell Dean Kimpfbeck
item.content:encoded:
Lime Ridge - Russell Dean Kimpfbeck, age 83, of Lime Ridge, formerly of Baraboo, passed away on Wednesday, August 24, 2016 at the Sauk County Health Care Center. He was born on Dec. 15, 1932 in Leland, the son of Ludwig and Violet (Geise) Kimpfbeck. Russell graduated from Baraboo High School in June of 1950 and served as Sergeant in Company H, 128th Infantry of the Wisconsin National Guard. On June 9, 1956, he was united in marriage to Patricia Jorg in Dubuque, Iowa. They lived their entire life in the Baraboo area. Russ worked for the Railroad for a short time and then became an electrician for the remainder of his life working for the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Union Local 159 as a foreman. In his spare time, he enjoyed playing cards with his friends and was an avid fisherman. Russ was a big supporter of the Green Bay Packers and Wisconsin Badgers. Survivors include his children, daughter, Debra (Terry) Smelcer of Lime Ridge, and son, Richard (Heather) Kimpfbeck of Baraboo; grandchild, Lacee Smelcer; special friend, Ruth Combs; his faithful dog, Gus; and several nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents and wife, Russ was preceded in death by two brothers, Jim and Ken. Funeral services will be held at 1:30 p.m. on Monday, Aug. 29, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo, with Pastor Elizabeth Jacob officiating. Visitation will be from 12 noon until time of service. Interment will take place in Walnut Hill Cemetery. Memorials may be given to the Sauk County Humane Society or the Sauk County Health Care Center. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Keith Gordon Wilkinson
item.content:encoded:
Keith Gordon Wilkinson, 82, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully at St. Clare Hospital on Friday, August 12, 2016 after a brief and courageous fight with lung cancer. Keith served in the United States Navy from 1951-1955 on the USS Brownson and USS Hazelwood and saw combat during the Korean War. After being honorably discharged, he began his lengthy career in manufacturing working for Flambaeu Plastics, Industrial Coils and Big Joe Mfg. After his career in manufacturing, Keith co-owned and operated Wilkinson's Cleaning and Painting Services with his wife, Beverly, until retirement. Keith loved to watch his beloved Cubbies and Packers as well as kid around with everyone he came in contact with. Survivors include his wife, Beverly; two children, Michele (Tom) Schaefer and Wayne Wilkinson; brother-in-laws, William (Donna) Wiese, Peter Morton and Patrick Crary; sister-in-laws, Nancy (Gene) Jarstead and Dorothy Wiese; and many beloved nieces and nephews. In addition to his parents, Keith was preceded in death by four brothers and two sisters. Private services were held at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home with interment in Walnut Hill Cemetery. Military rites were provided by the Baraboo Veterans Honor Guard. Special thanks to the therapists at St. Clare Cardiac Rehab for the many years of support and encouragement that helped Keith improve his quality of life after suffering a severe stroke. The family would also like to thank the wonderful doctors and staff at St. Clare Hospital in both the ER and ComfortCare units. Their kindness and support have been invaluable to the family. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Richard "Dick" Curtis Knight
item.content:encoded:
Rock Springs, WI. - Richard “Dick” Curtis Knight, age 81, of Rock Springs, Wisconsin passed away peacefully, surrounded by his family on Tuesday, August 2, 2016, following a long illness. Richard was born on August 31, 1934, in Rockford, IL to Roscoe and Charlotte (Williams) Knight. Richard graduated from Rockford West High School in 1952 the same year he married Kathrine Marie Gibler, his high school sweetheart. He attended the University of Illinois, graduating in 1956 with a Bachelor of Science in Agriculture Economics. He began his career with Swift & Company, the meat processing company, upon graduation at their headquarters in Chicago. His 31-year career with Swift included numerous positions that found him, along with his growing family, moving around the States until he was named Senior Vice President of the company in 1975, returning to Chicago. In the intervening years, he held various positions – everything from lamb buyer to plant manager to labor negotiator. During his years with Swift, his business travels took him around the country and abroad. He was a committee member of the American Meat Institute (AMI) in Washington, DC. In the ensuing years he did consulting work in the fresh meats industry before founding his own company, Quality Pork Processors (QPP), a pork processing company in Austin, MN in 1987. Richard remained CEO of the company until his retirement in 2000. Richard and Kathrine bought a farm outside of Rock Springs, Wisconsin in 1979 as a weekend retreat for themselves and their family. Working outside around the farm brought him great joy. He welcomed tending to everyday chores, especially chopping firewood, which would be used for the evening campfires and for heating the farmhouse in the early days. After the Christmas holidays, the couple relaxed at their condo in Bonita Springs, FL. Richard enjoyed boating, golf and annual fishing trips to Canada, Brazil and other locations with friends and family. He enjoyed bridge and cribbage and delighted in teaching his children and grandchildren how to play chess along with other games that required thinking skills. Movies were an important family time event for both Richard and Kathrine. He loved all kinds of music and took great pleasure in singing around the piano with family, notably Christmas carol sing-alongs during the holidays. He and Kathrine were doting grandparents, never missing an opportunity to attend a football game, soccer or wrestling match, swimming competitions, piano recitals or basketball games. Richard was a lifelong history buff as well as a voracious reader of historical biographies. He was fascinated with the Civil War and was proud to be a direct descendent of Frank Pettis, a Civil War drummer boy from Wisconsin who is buried in the Reedsburg Cemetery. Throughout his life, Richard instilled a strong work ethic, loyalty and sense of justice in both his children and grandchildren. He demonstrated these principles through his business relationships and his many charitable community endeavors where he donated his time and expertise. He gave back to the community wherever he lived. In Scottsbluff, NE he was a member of the Rotary Club and President of the Scottsbluff/Gering United Chamber of Commerce. He was condo board president at his and Kathrine’s Florida home and the first Chairman of the Plan Commission for Excelsior Township, serving from the time of its formation in 2006. Richard and Kathrine were lifelong members of the Presbyterian Church (PCUSA), and both were active in whatever community church they joined. He served as a deacon, elder, Sunday school teacher, and in other volunteer capacities. He and Kathrine were members of both the First Presbyterian Church in Reedsburg and the First Presbyterian Church of Baraboo, where they created an Endowment Fund. His faith was a cornerstone of his life, and he took great comfort in the 23rd Psalm. He will be greatly missed. Beloved husband of Kathrine Marie for 57 years and loving father to Sarah Elizabeth (Bill) Adamson of Naperville, IL, Martha Ann (Jeff) Hinkle of Omaha, NE, Richard Curtis, Jr. (Jim Bailey) of Chicago, IL, Julia Jean Ethun Baraboo, WI (deceased), and Susan Elaine (Tony) Carlin of Bloomfield, NJ. His grandchildren are Jason Knight (Katie) Nolda of San Francisco, CA, Amanda Marie (Niall Wallace, fiancée) Hinkle of Brooklyn, NY, Matthew Jeffrey (Alicia) Hinkle of New Ulm, MN, Christopher Richard (Erica) Nolda of Manhattan Beach, CA, Brian Champion (Dena) Hinkle of White Bear Lake, MN, Erik Scott Ethun of Kenosha, WI, Kathrine Elizabeth (Travis) LeBlanc of Westminster, CO, Hannah Marie Ethun of Cottage Grove, WI, Connor Knight Carlin of Bloomfield, NJ, Grace Julia Carlin of Bloomfield, NJ. His great-grandchildren are Amelia Kathrine Hinkle, Greta Martha Hinkle, Sophie Diana Hinkle, Nora Clair Hinkle, Violet Belle Hinkle, True Grace Hinkle, Calvin Knight LeBlanc, and George James Nolda. In addition, Richard is survived by his sisters Geraldine Knight of San Clemente, CA, Janet (Jim) Wisner of Wonder Lake, IL and Susan Seaver of Crystal Lake, IL, Bill and Pat Gibler, (brother and sister-in-law) of Green Valley, AZ, Joe Gibler, (brother-in-law) of Rockford, IL and Frank and Rita Gibler (brother and sister-in-law) of Rockford, IL, as well as many nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his beloved parents, Roscoe and Charlotte Knight, his beloved wife Kathrine Marie (Gibler), their daughter, Julia Jean Ethun, for whom he and his wife created the Julia Knight Ethun Memorial Scholarship; a sister, Enola Woodard, a mother-in-law Marjorie Marie Gibler, a sister-in-law Frances Gibler Leneker, and sister-in-law Marguerite Gibler. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday, Aug. 6, 2016 at the First Presbyterian Church, 416 Ash St., Baraboo, with Pastor Lisa Taylor officiating. Visitation will take place at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, on Friday, Aug. 5, 2016 from 4:30 p.m. until 7 p.m. Burial will be in St. John's Cemetery in Rock Springs. Memorials may be given to the Lewy Body Dementia Association (LBDA), Parkinson Disease Foundation or Sauk County Health Care Center Foundation in Reedsburg, WI. The Knight family is very grateful for all the community support throughout Richard’s illness and would like particularly to thank Tami Stieve, Jill Corwith and the entire staff of the Sauk County Health Care Center, in Reedsburg, WI, for their compassionate care. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Gene Allen Zautke
item.content:encoded:
La Farge, WI. - Gene Allen Zautke, 54, of La Farge, passed away unexpectedly on Monday, Aug. 1, 2016 with his fiancee, Vicki Ozelis. Gene was born on Feb. 16, 1962 in Reedsburg, the son of Allen and Dorothy (Schmidt) Zautke. He was a graduate of Baraboo High School Class of 1981, he enlisted in the United States Air Force after graduation and received an honorably discharged. Gene was employed at Cropp Organic Valley, in Chaseburg, in the maintenance department. In his spare time, he enjoyed the outdoors and kept busy with various repair projects and spending time with family and friends. He will be truly missed by all who knew him. Survivors include his daughter, Amber; son, Allen; granddaughter, Gabbie; his mother, Dorothy; a brother, Steve (Judy) Zautke; two sisters, Lavonne Zautke and Linda McWane; several nieces, nephews other relatives and friends. He is further survived by his step-children, Ian Ozelis, Rae Ann (Steve) Pyfferoen, Daina Ozelis and Peter Ozelis; and step-grandchildren, Sammy and Kaley. He was preceded in death by his father, Allen August Zautke; and his brother, Larry. Memorial services will be held at a later date in August, at Devil’s Lake State Park. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the family. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Vicki Beth Ozelis
item.content:encoded:
La Farge, WI. - Vicki Beth Ozelis, 55, of La Farge, passed away unexpectedly on Monday, Aug. 1, 2016 with her fiance’, Gene Zautke. Vicki was born on March 10, 1961 in La Grange, Illinois. She was the daughter of Richard and Audrey (Ofelt) Choutka. Vicki was a 1979 graduate of Lyon’s Township High School in La Grange. She enjoyed cooking for her family and friends. Vicki knew the importance of family and dedicated as much time as possible to being with her loved ones. She was known to volunteer her time where-ever needed or possible. Vicki had a unique love for the outdoors and was very conscious of the environment. Survivors include her daughters, Rae (Steve) Pyfferoen, Daina Ozelis; sons, Ian (Amanda Simon) and Peter Ozelis; grandchildren, Sammy and Kaley; a sister, Bev (Darin Antoniewicz) Choutka, and his daughter, D.J. In addition, she is survived by her step-children, Allen and Amber Zautke; and step-granddaughter, Gabbie. She was preceded in death by her parents, Richard and Audrey Choutka. Memorial services will be held at a later date in August, at Devil’s Lake State Park. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the family. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Elgi A. Toman
item.content:encoded:
Elgi Toman, age 80, passed on with loving family by his side at St. Mary’s Hospital in Madison, unexpectedly on July 28, 2016. He was born Sept. 15, 1935 in Flasher, North Dakota to John and Adel (Slavick) Toman and grew up on the family farm. On Dec. 6, 1958, two days after graduating from North Dakota State University, Elgi married Darleen (Patzer) Toman, the love of his life for over 57 years. Elgi and Darleen’s love story started through correspondence while Elgi was a foreign exchange student during college, and they saw each other for the first time when he returned from England to Jamestown, North Dakota in 1957. Elgi and Darleen lived in Jamestown where Elgi was an insurance agent for National Farmers Union Insurance. In 1967 Elgi and Darleen moved to Baraboo with their three children to continue his insurance career with the company. As a Chartered Life Underwriter (CLU) Elgi started Badger Insurance Specialists, a general insurance agency, which he owned and operated from 1974 until his retirement. Elgi was a loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather. He was known for his friendly smile and kind heart, and being a loyal and trustworthy friend. Elgi never met a stranger, and he could make anyone laugh. Along with Darleen, he was an active member of St. Paul’s Lutheran Church since 1967. He participated in many civic and professional groups. Elgi was a long-time, dedicated Mason, belonging to the Baraboo Masonic Lodge #34 Free and Accepted Masons. He also was a Zor Shriner, as a member of the Vacationland Shrine Club, since 1982. Elgi is survived by his wife, Darleen; their three children and their spouses, Dennis Toman (Lynne) of Greensboro, North Carolina, Brian Toman of Reedsburg, and Kari Jefferson (Jose) of Holmen. He is also survived by five grandchildren and spouses, Austin Toman (Elaina), Kyle Toman (Sami Spedoske), Andrew Toman, Jeremiah and Jonas Jefferson; along with his older brothers and sisters, Adel, Leo, John and Irene; and many nieces and nephews. Visitation will take place from 1-3 p.m., Sunday, July 31, 2016, at Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo. Private interment will be in Walnut Hill Cemetery. A Masonic service will be held at 3 p.m. by the Baraboo Masonic Lodge #34 Free and Accepted Masons. item.title: Betty R. Brown
item.content:encoded:
Betty R. Brown, 95, of Baraboo, formerly of Rock Falls, Illinois, passed away on Sunday, July 24, 2016 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center in Baraboo. Betty was born on March 31, 1921 in Rock Falls, Illinois, the daughter of Robert and Mayme Brown. She graduated from Rock Falls Township High School in March of 1939, and worked as the librarian for Coloma Township Library for over 55 years, with 35 of those years as head librarian. Betty was a life-long member of the United Methodist Church in Rock Falls. Survivors include a nephew, Robert (Mary) Willett of Baraboo; two great-nephews; a great-niece; three great-great-nephews and two great-great-nieces. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by a sister, Lillian Mac Lennan. Memorial services will take place at 2 p.m. on Saturday, July 30, 2016 at McDonald Funeral Home, 1002 12th Ave., Rock Falls, IL. item.title: Paul G. Phillips
item.content:encoded:
Paul G. Phillips, 62, of Baraboo, died on Sunday, July 17, 2016 at his home. Paul was born on May 5, 1954, in Reedsburg, the son of Donald Eugene and Gloria Mae (Fish) Phillips. Paul was raised on a farm near Lime Ridge during his school years. After graduating high school in 1972, he enlisted in the United States Marine Corps for four years. After being honorably discharged, he went to college in Oshkosh. Soon after college, he began working for Friede Brothers Construction in Reedsburg for over 25 years. Paul loved his farm situated in the Baraboo bluffs. He had many animals and grew a large garden every year. He leaves behind his wife of 45 years, Phyllis Phillips; three sons, Jereme, Jesse and Justin; five grandchildren; one great-grandchild; two brothers, Donald and Audley; and many other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents, Paul was preceded in death by two sisters, Angela and Gloria “Dale” Phillips; and several aunts, uncles and cousins. Memorial services will be held at 2 p.m. on Sunday, July 24, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo, with Pastor Amos Vande Hei officiating. Visitation will be from 1 p.m. until time of service at the funeral home.

item.title: Janice Mac Dougall Patterson
item.content:encoded:
Janice M. Patterson, 87, of Baraboo, formerly of Rockford, Ill., passed away peacefully on Saturday, July 16, 2016 at Oak Park Place surrounded by her friends. A native of Rockford, she was born January 1, 1929, the daughter of Leslie R. Mac Dougall and Norma Eddie. She lived nearly her entire life there and her sister was Phyllis Mac Dougall Hyland of Rockford. Janice was a member of the first graduating class of West High School in 1946. She graduated from the University of Illinois with a B.S. in journalism and communication, class of 1950 and was a member of Zeta Tau Alpha sorority. On Dec. 10, 1954, Janice was united in marriage to Wesley H. Patterson, Architect, AIA, at the Second Congregational Church in Rockford. Janice was a devoted wife and mother, was a member of the Rockford Women’s Club, and an active volunteer and life-long member of the Second Congregational Church in Rockford. She was a gourmet cook, an animal lover and bird watcher, enjoyed reading, telling stories, painting and drawing. Janice and her husband were some of the first promoters of naturalized gardens and living spaces. They appreciated and preserved the native wild flowers and plants of their wooded neighborhood where she lived for 54 years. Janice was very proud of her Scottish heritage and loved the skirl of the bagpipes. Her mother’s family, George and Annis Dyson, were pioneers in the Rockford area, Burritt Township, and first purchased their land in the 1840’s. She was planning to attend her father’s relatives’ 115th Liddle Family Reunion this September in the Rockton area. Janice recently moved to Oak Park Place Independent Living in Baraboo, WI., to be near her daughter, Amy. She enjoyed her new friends in Baraboo, participating in the group activities, fieldtrips and exercise classes. She remained curious and was a life-long learner. Survivors include her daughter, Lisa (Thomas) Raterman of Chicago, Ill.; her son, Robert (Laura) Patterson of Delavan, WI., and her daughter, Amy (Steven) Anderson of Baraboo, WI.; seven grandchildren, Elizabeth and Matthew Raterman, Gordon, Olivia and Cameron Patterson, Eric and Sarah Anderson; several cousins, nieces, nephews and many friends. In addition to her parents, Janice was preceded in death by her husband, Wesley in 1978; her son, David in 2012; and her sister, Phyllis in 1985. Memorial services will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, July 28, 2016 at the Second Congregational First Presbyterian Church, 318 N. Church St., Rockford, with Pastor Becky Erbe officiating. In addition, there will be a memorial service at 4 p.m. on Friday, August 12, 2016 at Oak Park Place Independent Living, 800 Waldo St., Baraboo, WI. Memorials may be designated to: JDRF (Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation) Illinois Chapter, 1 N. LaSalle St., Suite 1200, Chicago, IL. 60602 JDRF.org. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Marguerite Begnoche
item.content:encoded:
Marguerite Begnoche, 101, of Baraboo, formerly of Harvey, Illinois, and Santa Monica, California, passed away quietly on Thursday, July 7, 2016 at Oak Park Place in Baraboo. “Detes” as she had been dubbed in childhood, had been a physical education teacher and department head at Thornton Township High school in Harvey Illinois. She did extensive traveling during her summer free time, visiting China, Israel, Australia, Mexico, Europe to name a few. After retiring from her field, she relocated to California where she worked at a copy shop in Santa Monica until the age of 75. She moved to Wisconsin to live with her niece, Doris (Douglas) Wight, for seven years, then moved into the Reese Memorial and finally settled at Oak Park Place. Marguerite greatly loved family and friends. She enjoyed making crossword puzzles, reading, listening to music and playing cards. She was popular with her senior aerobics swimming group, remaining mentally alert and witty to the end. Survivors include several nieces and nephews. She was preceded in death by her parents, Frank and Lucy Begnoche; her brothers, John and Romeo; a sister, Gabrielle Senesac; nephew, Ronald Senesac; niece, Elaine; aunt and uncle, Carrie and Severe Milot; and other cherished relatives and friends. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved this outstanding woman. Per Marguerite’s wishes, no formal services are planned at this time. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: William "Bill" Bockenhauer
item.content:encoded:
Merrimac - William “Bill” Bockenhauer, 63, of Merrimac, passed away on Tuesday, July 5, 2016 at his residence. Bill was born on Sept. 29, 1952 in Winona, Minnesota, the son of Harlan and Dolores (Stinson) Bockenhauer. Bill was a 1974 graduate of Winona State University and received a degree in Biology and Earth Science. He then joined the United States Navy in March of 1975 and went to Hospital Corps School in San Diego, California. He served the remaining tour of duty at Camp Pendleton, California. On Nov. 29, 1975 he was united in marriage to Kimberly Kearney in Owatonna, Minnesota. After being honorably discharged from the navy, he became employed at the V. A. Hospital in Madison as a Hemodialysis Technician. He then taught science for over 28 years in the Deforest and Baraboo Public School Systems and retired in 2004. Bill was an avid gardener and outdoorsman. Survivors include his loving wife of 40 years, Kimberly of Merrimac; two children, B.J. (Keri) Bockenhauer of Stoughton and Dori Bockenhauer of Baraboo; two grandchildren, Kinzie and Hoffman; mother-in-law, Ollie Kearney of Baraboo; and many other relatives and friends. Bill was preceded in death by his parents, grand-parents and father-in-law. Memorial services will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday, July 9, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo, with Yvonne Smith officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home from 9 a.m. until time of service. Military honors will be provided by the VFW Greenwood Memorial Post 987. In lieu of flowers, memorials to Muscular Dystrophy Association or U.W. Children’s Hospital would be appreciated. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Inge Martha Jernander
item.content:encoded:
Inge Martha Jernander, 80, of Baraboo, passed away on Monday, June 27, 2016 at the Greenway Manor Nursing Home in Spring Green with her family by her side. She was born on March 2, 1936 in Nieder-Weistritz, Germany, the daughter of Fritz and Martha (Rother) Kellert. She met the love of her life, Burton Jernander and they were united in marriage on April 10, 1957 in Aschaffenburg, Germany. The union was blessed with four children. Over the years, the family relocated to various army bases before finally settling in Baraboo in 1972. She spent many years working as a certified nursing assistant at St. Clare Hospital working in various departments. Inge was a great homemaker, an avid gardener and took great joy in tending to her flower, vegetable and raspberry gardens. She especially enjoyed traveling and visiting with her family and grandchildren. Survivors include children, Joachim “Joe” (Tina) Jernander of Dublin, Georgia, Betty (Randy) Van Diver of Janesville, Susan Bochler of Baraboo, and Bernard (Lisa) Jernander of Reedsburg; seven grandchildren, Christopher Jernander, Nicole Booker, Miranda Coplien, David and Brian Kyster, Kelsey Draves and Alex Jernander; four very precious great-grandchildren, Ryan, Hunter and Sydney Coplien, and August Draves. Inge is further survived by a brother, Winfried (Ursula) Kellert; a sister, Barbara (Wilfred) Zimmer; a sister-in-law, Gertrude Kellert, all of Germany; and many other relatives and friends. In addition to her husband and parents, Inge was preceded in death by a brother, Hans Kellert of Germany; mother-in-law, Selma Jernander of Baraboo; sister-in-law, Charlene (James) Seymour of Baraboo; two brother-in-laws, LeVern Jernander of Santa Rosa, California and Dewey (Millie) Jernander of Milwaukee. Funeral services will be at 11 a.m. on Saturday, July 2, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, with Deacon Ron Pickar officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home from 10 a.m. until time of service. Interment will take place in Walnut Hill Cemetery, Baraboo. In lieu of flowers memorials to Sacred Heart School in Reedsburg or St. Clare Hospital Auxiliary in Baraboo would be appreciated. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home is assisting the family.

item.title: John Phillip Mueller
item.content:encoded:
Portage - John Phillip Mueller, 82, of rural Portage, died peacefully on Monday, May 30, 2016 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. John was born on Oct. 20, 1933 in La Valle, the son of Valentine George and Irene Theresa (Gruber) Mueller. He was united in marriage to Patricia Ann Chick on Aug. 24, 1957 at St. Joseph Catholic Church in Baraboo. At an early age, John began working side by side with his father at the Carr Valley Cheese Factory in La Valle, and then on the family farms. In 1941, at the age of eight, the family moved to a farm near Baraboo. In 1955, the family moved to their present farm in Caledonia Township in rural Portage. John earned his license as a Journeyman’s Plumber working full time for Schadde Plumbing & Heating in Baraboo while helping on the farm along with his six brothers. In 1969 he and Pat took over the family farm and with their seven sons assisting, increased working acreage by purchasing neighboring properties and the farm became Pine Island Farm, Inc. Upon retirement John enjoyed purchasing antique John Deere tractors, also having time to visit with relatives, neighbors and friends from earlier days. Grandchildren brightened his days tremendously by coming to John and Pat’s home for a visit and their ice cream treat with Grandpa. John is survived by his wife of 57 years, Patricia; his sons, Dennis of Greenwood Village, Colorado, Robert (Sherry) and their children, Ben, Grace, Irene, Esther, Bart, and Olivia; Richard (Helen) and their children, Tricia, Katie and Steve; William; John Jr. (Kathleen) and their son, Joshua; Andrew (Tammy) and their children, Erin, Joe and Megan; Tony (Shawna) and their children, Taylor, Austin and Riley, all of Portage. Six great-grandchildren, Genevieve, Lucca, Constance, Judson, Makayla, and Little John. In addition, John is also survived by his siblings, Grace Barden of Pardeeville, Harold Mueller of Baraboo, Marvin (Jeanie) Mueller of Baraboo, Michael (Diane) Mueller of New Braunfels, Texas, Mary Jane (Philip) Manthey of Pardeeville, Joan (Jerry) Henke of Rose Hill, Kansas, and Catherine (David) Grinde of Deforest; brother- in-laws, Eber Janzen of Reedsburg, Dan Krejchik of Portage, Gilbert (Kay) Chick of Onalaska, and James Chick of Minneapolis, Minnesota; sisters-in-law, Joyce Mueller, Arbor Vitae and Nancy Mueller of Baraboo; and many nieces, nephews other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents, John was preceded in death by his siblings, Helen Janzen, Paul, Eugene and David Mueller, Monica Krekchik; daughter-in-law, Lana Mueller on April 22, 2016; brother-in-law, David Barden; and niece, Jodie Mueller. A Memorial Mass will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, June 9, 2016 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 304 East St., Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church on Thursday from 10 a.m. until time of Mass. Interment will take place in St. Mary’s Catholic Cemetery, Portage. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family would like to thank Dr. Thomas Flygt and the staff at St. Clare Hospital and St. Clare Meadows Care Center for the dedicated care given to John.

item.title: Opal Carol Messner
item.content:encoded:
Opal Carol Messner, 98, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully on Friday, May 27, 2016 at St. Clare Hospital. Opal was born on Oct. 6, 1917 in Avon, South Dakota, the daughter of William and Alma (Lemke) Moersfelder. On March 12, 1949 she married Andrew Messner in Dubuque, Iowa. Opal worked for the Federal Weather Bureau in Milwaukee. She enjoyed creating weather maps and compiling weather data. She enjoyed reading, creating art work and being a homemaker raising her four boys. She is survived by her husband of 67 years, Andrew of Baraboo; her sons, Erick (Audrey) of Baraboo, Kris (Melissa) of Mequon, Tod (Char) of Plymouth, Jon (Diane) of South Milwaukee; three grandchildren, Tristan, Brittany and Steven (Sarah); two great-grandchildren, Andrew and Aiden; and other relatives and friends. Janesville - Lois Joan O’Hara, 83, of Janesville passed away peacefully on Thursday, May 26, 2016 at St. Clare Hospice House in Baraboo. Lois was born on July 28, 1932 in Grand Forks, North Dakota, the daughter of Lyle and Velma (Brown) Mowris. She was a 1950 graduate of Thief River Falls High School in Thief River Falls, Minnesota. item.title: Ronald Roger Alley
item.content:encoded:
Ronald Roger Alley, 77, of Baraboo, passed away on Wednesday, May 25, 2016 at St. Clare Hospital surrounded by his loving family. Ronald was born on Feb. 21, 1939 in Baraboo, the son of Roger and Frances (Wedekind) Alley. He attended Baraboo Schools and was united in marriage to Betty Bethke on May 15, 1965 at the First Presbyterian Church in Baraboo. Ronald was employed as a draftsman with several local companies in the Baraboo area. He enjoyed reading, hunting, fishing, trapshooting, model railroading and visiting with family and friends. He was a member of the Circus City and Merrimac Trap Shooting club. Survivors include his wife of 51 years, Betty; three children, Linda (Dave) Richardson of Baraboo, Theresa (Dustin Stoor) Martz of Baraboo, Jeffrey Alley of Portage; seven grandchildren, Michael, Miranda, Morgan, Brandon, Justin, Sierra and Ben; a sister, Sharon (Wayne) Benseman of Janesville; a brother, David (Robin) Alley of North Freedom; and other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents, Ronald was preceded in death by three brothers, Marvin, Dennis, Brian; and a sister, Faye. A celebration of Ronald’s life will be held from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. on Saturday, Sept. 17, 2016 at Max Hill Park on Connie Road in West Baraboo. Please bring memories and stories to share. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home is assisting the family. The family would like to extend a special thank you to Dr. Ethan Carlson and staff for the special care given to Ronald.

Kevin Ketelboeter, 64, of Baraboo, passed away on Tuesday, May 24, 2016 at Agrace HospiceCare in Fitchburg. Kevin was born on Oct. 1, 1951 in Madison, the son of Ruben and Mavis (Glimme) Ketelboeter. item.title: Joseph "Joe" Anthony Raschka
item.content:encoded:
Merrimac - Joseph “Joe” Raschka, 62, of Merrimac, passed away peacefully in his home surrounded by loving family on Tuesday, May 10, 2016 after a year-long struggle with cancer. Joe was born on June 13, 1953 in Baraboo, the son of Rudolph “Rudy” and Evelyn (Herbes) Raschka. He grew up in the town of Merrimac where he continued to live and build his own paradise out in the country. Joe was a 1971 graduate of Sauk Prairie High School and worked at Oscar Mayer Foods Corporation for 32 years, August 1971 through November 2003. He was able to enjoy the life of retirement for 13 years. Even though cancer took the life of his dominant arm (left), he was determined to do what he loved. In that last year he was able to shoot a pheasant out of the air and shoot his deer with his non-dominant hand. Amazing! As many of us know, fences never stopped him. He loved to walk and hunt the woods for Morel mushrooms, canoe the Baraboo River, wade the creeks for water crest, and best of all; go for a swim at least weekly at Devils Lake. He also enjoyed to fish and harvest his gardens. Merrimac was his home in which he provided entertainment to his friends through what he called the “Joe Show.” He was unique and touched so many hearts. No matter who you were, or what background you were from, Joe was your friend. Joe is survived by his loving daughter, Michelle Fandrich (Bill); three courageous grandsons in which he was so proud of and will carry on some of his traditions, Dalton, Payton and Brayton Fandrich; his brothers, Francis Raschka (Debbie), Herb Raschka (Dianne); his sisters, Rosemary Wendt, Jane Coffel (Ron), Rita Collins (Tom); nephews, Derek, Dave and Michael Raschka, Ben Wendt; nieces, Lindsey and Angela Coffell, Kristi Raschka; and his ex-wife, Mary Lou Bartelt. Joe was proceeded in death by his parents; a brother-in-law, Larry Wendt; and a nephew, Nicholas Wendt. A celebration of Joe’s life will take place on Saturday, June 25, 2016, from 12 noon to 7 p.m. at the Merrimac Conservation Club, Hwy 78, Merrimac. The band will begin to play at 3 p.m. Please bring a dish to pass or just yourself. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family would like to express their sincere gratitude for all the love and support from family and friends during this chapter of his life. A special thank you to the staff from Home Health for providing care and love during Joe’s last days; a big thank you to his card playing buddies that gave him something to look forward to each week; and to everyone that visited him and loved him as much as we do. “Nature is good” and “The length of life doesn’t guarantee a better quality of life”. Joe.

<]]>

item.title: Wanda M. McArthur
item.content:encoded:
Wanda M. McArthur, 91, of Baraboo passed away on Tuesday, May 10, 2016 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. Wanda was born on Sept. 21, 1924 in the Town of Freedom, to George and Adelia (Koenig) Schutz. She was baptized in St. John’s Lutheran Church, Baraboo, and confirmed at St. John’s Lutheran Church, Rock Springs in 1938. Wanda was united in marriage to Robert M. McArthur on May 7, 1954 at the Lutheran parsonage in Baraboo. He preceded her in death in 1992. Wanda was instrumental in the formation of Our Savior Lutheran Church and was a charter member. She also held many church offices during her lifetime. She was an avid reader of mystery novels and her happiest times were spent with her grandchildren who she dearly loved. She is survived by her son, Steven A. McArthur of Chicago, Illinois; two grandchildren, Tatiana (Jonathan) Constable of Green Bay and Ian (Katharine) McArthur of Baraboo; two sisters, Eunice McCoy of Baraboo and Lois Schrimpf of Lake City, Minnesota; family member, Colleen McArthur of Eden Prairie, Minnesota; and four nieces and two nephews. In addition to her parents and husband, Wanda was preceded in death by a sister, Lucille Rohde in 2004. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday, May 14, 2016 at Our Savior Lutheran Church, Baraboo, with Pastor David Jensen officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 a.m. until time of service. Burial will take place in Walnut Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the church for purposes of the annual shoe-box children’s fund. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Rochelle Robkin
item.content:encoded:
Rochelle Robkin, 75, of Baraboo passed away on Tuesday, May 3, 2016 at St. Clare Hospice House in Baraboo. Rochelle was born on May 28, 1940 in Newark, N.J., the daughter of Leon and Pearl (Lombozo) Merzon. Rochelle attended City Terrace Elementary School, Los Angeles, and continued her education at LA Community College, the University of California at Los Angeles, BA; University of Massachusetts at Amherst, MA; and the University of Wisconsin-Madison, PhD. Rochelle loved music and reading. She was a prolific artist and a career teacher of art to children and adults at Baraboo Elementary and Senior High School, the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and U.W. Baraboo/Sauk County. She was active in the community and was a member of several organizations, including the International Crane Foundation, the Baraboo Optimist Club, the Baraboo Public Arts Association, the Sauk County Art Association, and Al. Ringling Theatre Friends. She was co-founder of Stage III Theater for Kids, and began the Souper Bowl program at the Baraboo High School. Rochelle led a loving, rich and rewarding life with family, friends, colleagues and students. She can be best described as a teacher in all meanings of the word. To teach is to “pay it forward” with no expectation and no way to know what its effect will be. Rochelle dedicated her life to this, helping others to find the possibilities within them and the resources to discover and then build their own path to become what they wanted to be. The postings now flooding onto Facebook from her students and friends tell a small part of how marvelous she was doing just that. Her light continues to blaze in all those she touched. Rochelle is survived by her husband of 55 years, Eugene “Gene” Robkin of Baraboo; her son, David and his partner, Laura Brody of Altadena, CA.; her son, Michael Robkin and his wife, Dalia of Woodland Hills, CA.; two grandchildren, Nathaniel and Aden of Woodland Hills, CA.; her sister, Lenore Doran; and two nephews, Collin and Andrew; many cousins and countless friends. She was preceded in death by her parents, Leon and Pearl Merzon. Funeral services will take place on Wednesday, May 11, 2016 at 11 a.m. at Eden Memorial Park Cemetery in Mission Hills, CA. There will be a Memorial visitation on Saturday, June 11, 2016 from 1-5 p.m. at the Al. Ringling Mansion, 623 Broadway St., Baraboo. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to the Al. Ringling Theatre Friends, the International Crane Foundation, Stage III Theater for Kids, or the Baraboo Optimist Club. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Jean (Paske) Stovall
item.content:encoded:
Jean (Paske) Stovall, 85, of Baraboo, was called home by her Lord from Meadow View Assisted Living on Saturday, April, 23, 2016. She was born to Albert and Lucille (Koepp) Paske in Baraboo on April 9, 1931. Upon graduating from Baraboo High School, Jean moved to Milwaukee to work for General Motors and AC Spark Plug as an expeditor in purchasing for 35 years. Upon retiring, she moved back to Baraboo. Some of her hobbies included playing softball and bowling, where she attended bowling tournaments in Las Vegas. Jean is survived by her brothers, Philip (Joyce) Paske of Pembine and Milton (Artha) Paske of Beaumont, Mississippi; nephews, David, John and Christopher Paske; and special friends, Nancy Machtan and Barbara Schneider. She will be missed by her cousins and many friends. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, April 28, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor Ervine Vomhof officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home from 9:30 a.m. until time of service. Interment will take place in Indian Farm Cemetery, Merrimac.

item.title: June Marie High
item.content:encoded:
Richland Center - June Marie High, 60, of Richland Center, formerly of Baraboo, quietly passed away on Tuesday, April 19, 2016 at the Able House in Richland Center. June was born on Oct. 3, 1955 in Baraboo, the daughter of Bob and Edith (Westcott) High. She filled her life with laughter, music, bowling, camps, workshop, ARC activities, family and friends. She will be truly missed by all who knew her. Survivors include a sister, Peggy High; and several cousins from all over the United States who have many loving fond memories of her. A celebration of June’s life will take place at 11:30 a.m. on Thursday, May 19, 2016 at the Farm Kitchen Restaurant, 5718 Hwy 123, Baraboo. item.title: Shirley L. Breneman
item.content:encoded:
Shirley L. Breneman, 82, of Baraboo, passed away on Tuesday, April 12, 2016 at her residence. Shirley was born on Sept. 7, 1933 in Portage, the daughter of Edwin and Helen (Lockwood) Breneman. She was a graduate of Portage High School and moved to Milwaukee where she lived for over 40 years. While in Milwaukee, Shirley was employed at the Northwestern Mutual Insurance Company as a loan advisor until her retirement. In December of 2015, she moved to Baraboo to be with her brother, sister-in-law and niece, and enjoyed gardening and attending estate sales in the area. Survivors include her sister, Irene A. Breneman of Baraboo; brother, Kenneth D. (Ruth) Breneman of Baraboo; nieces and nephews, David, Vicky, Tammy (Richard) and Carl Breneman, and Teahanna (Charles) Olson; great nieces and great nephews, Kelsie (Stephen) Breneman, Cody (Lindsey) and Colton Holsaple, Kailee and Ciera Breneman, Alexander Olson and special great nieces, Trinidy and Lileyanne Fleming; great-great nephew, Julian Breneman; great-great niece, Arianna Holsaple; and special friends, Kris, Judy, Cheryl, Audrey and Jack (Carol) Kennedy. She was preceded in death by her parents, and several aunts, uncles, and other relatives. Memorial services will be held at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, April 20, 2016 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo, with Pastor Karen Hofstad officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home from 10 a.m. until time of service. The family would like to thank Dr. Hannah, the staff at Home Health United Hospice, and Recovery Health for their care given to Shirley. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Marian T. Finger
item.content:encoded:
Marian T. Finger, 89, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, April 5, 2016 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. Marian was born on Sept. 7, 1926 in De Pere, the daughter of Clem and Josephine Jauquet. On Feb. 9, 1957 she was united in marriage to Robert Anthony Finger of Columbus. He preceded her in death on March 11, 2003. After earning her Master’s degree in social work, Marian served for two years with the Red Cross and was stationed in Japan. She faithfully served as a social worker for the Reedsburg Public School system for over 30 years where she enjoyed the confidence and deep friendship of many. In addition, Marian engaged in a number of volunteer activities which included the Food Pantry, St. Clare Hospital, ESL tutor among other activities. She was a lifelong member of St. Joseph Catholic Church. Marian was a woman of grace and wisdom who positively influenced everyone she met, with her great sense of humor, ability to always laugh, her quick wit kept her feisty and fun to be around. She was a woman of prayer and quiet faith, and will be greatly missed by all. Marian is survived by her four children, Ruth (Doug) Wagely of Spokane, Washington, David Finger of Prairie du Sac, Catherine Finger of Grayslake, Illinois and Peter Finger of Elgin, Illinois; six grandchildren, Daniel R. (Sara) Finger, Catherine Wagley, Rachel (Ted) McCann, Martha Wagley, Greta Wagley and Ema Wagley; a brother, James (Joyce) Jauquet of Sagola, Michigan; and many nieces, nephews, other relatives and good friends. In addition to her husband, Marian was preceded in death by her siblings, Joseph, Clem, Herbert, Katheryn, Geraldine and other dearly departed relatives. A Mass of Christian burial will be held at 10 a.m. on Saturday, April, 9, 2016 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 9 a.m. until time of Mass. Private family interment will be held in St. Joseph Cemetery. Memorials in memory of Marian may be given to St. Joseph’s Catholic Church. The family would like to thank the medical staff at St. Meadows Care Center for the wonderful care and concern given to Marian during her stay. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Pamela Gail Head
item.content:encoded:
Pamela Gail Head, 78, of Baraboo, passed away on Sunday, April 3, 2016 at her residence. Pamela was born on July 18, 1937 in White Bear Lake, Minnesota, the daughter of Bert and Inez (Oyan) Head. She was married to Richard M. Beyer and together they had four children. Pamela enjoyed living in Baraboo and was employed as a professional transcriptionist for the area medical clinics. In her younger years, she enjoyed cooking and caring for her family. She especially enjoyed watching Badger football/basketball and taking care of her cats. Survivors include her four children, Richard Beyer, Robin Larkin, Gina and Scott Beyer; several grandchildren; and a special friend, Virginia Louise Good. Pamela lived a good, caring life and will be greatly missed by many. Per her wishes, no services will be held. Memorials may be given to the Sauk County Humane Society in her memory. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: June H. Peterson
item.content:encoded:
June Peterson, 92, of Baraboo, died peacefully on March 31, 2016 at St. Mary’s Hospital in Madison with her family at her bedside. She was born on June 10, 1923 in Sparta, the daughter of Fred and Adele Steel. On May 24, 1946 she married Arnold “Pete” Peterson in Sparta. They moved to Baraboo in 1956 where Pete became co-owner of the Fisher Drug store. He preceded her in death on Jan. 30, 1995. June was one of the first long distance telephone switchboard operators, and was a realtor for McGann Reality for many years. She was a member of PEO and the Baraboo Country Club where she had the thrill of making a hole-in-one. Most of all, June enjoyed ladies and couples bridge clubs where many cherished lifelong friendships were born and blossomed. She was a devoted member of the First United Methodist Church and in her younger years loved singing in the choir especially during Advent when the Messiah was sung. June is survived by two daughters, Judith Peterson Shepherd of Madison and Nancy (David) Platt of Spokane, Washington; a son, Jerome (Vicki) Peterson of South Milwaukee; five grandsons, Michael (Lena), Benjamin (Nia), John (Kerri), Jeff (Michelle) and Phillip (Mary); 10 great grandchildren; a sister-in-law, Jane Richgruber of Sparta; and other relatives and friends. In addition to her husband, Pete, June was preceded in death by two sisters, one brother, and a dearly loved companion, Gaylon Olson. Graveside services will take place at 11 a.m. on Friday, April 22, 2016 at Mount Hope Cemetery, Sparta, with Pastor Marianne Cotter officiating. Following the service, everyone is welcome to join the family for a luncheon and fellowship. Memorials in memory of June may be given to the Sauk County Meals on Wheels program. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The grandsons will miss her wit and energy. Her children can’t find the words to describe her. She was one special lady we loved so much.

item.title: Amy Katherine Yoder
item.content:encoded:
Amy Katherine Yoder, 51, of Baraboo, passed away on Monday, March 28, 2016 at the Columbia County Heath Care Center. Amy was born on June 23, 1964 in Baraboo, the daughter of Arlan and Patricia Dunse. She was a 1982 graduate of Baraboo High School and on October 4, 1986 she married Brett Roznos of Merrimac. She worked various jobs in the area which included Devil’s Head Resort, and was an EMT/Firefighter for the Village of Merrimac Fire Department for nine years. Amy was an excellent cook, singer and loving mother. She enjoyed visiting with family and friends, and will be dearly missed by everyone who knew her. Amy is survived by her two children, Danielle (Matt) Smith and Cody Roznos; her mother and father, Patricia “Pat” Dunse and Arlan (Maurine) Dunse; a grandchild, Bailey Smith; three sisters, Angela Dunz, Allison (Gary) Goetz and Anita (Rod) Wortley; a niece and nephew, Brittany and Riley Wortley; former husband and friend, Robert Yoder and his family; and countless other relatives and friends. She was preceded in death by her grandparents, Lloyd (Louise) Hauge and Carl (Celia) Dunse. Memorial Services will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday April 9, 2016 at Walnut Hill Bible Church, 1900 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor Dave Hutchens officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 a.m. until time of service. Burial will take place at a later date. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family.

item.title: Terrance Frank "Terry" Teelin
item.content:encoded:
Terrance Frank “Terry” Teelin, of Baraboo, passed away on Saturday, March 19, 2016 at his residence after suffering from C.O.P.D. Terry was born in Herkimer, New York, the son of Willard “Pete” and Erma (Getman) Teelin. Terry attended Baraboo schools, graduated from Carroll College, and then enlisted in the United States Navy where he achieved the rank of lieutenant. While in the Navy he met his beloved wife, Una Kelly Corcoran. On completion of his duty, he was honorably discharged and they moved to upstate New York where Terry was employed by General Electric. Terry and Una eventually moved with their three girls to Baraboo where Terry worked for his father at Teel Plastics until his retirement. Terry is survived by his wife, Una; three children, Kelly, Laura (Doug) Baragar and Tom (Joy) Teelin; six grandchildren, William and Piper Baragar, Dylan, Brendan, Nora and Joseph Teelin; his brother, Tim (Amy) Teelin; two sisters, Lynda (Ron) Baraganz and Tracie (Ray) Mandli. Terry was preceded in death by his beloved daughter, Maureen; and many other dear relatives. Our family would like to thank Dr. Randy Krszjzaniek for his excellent care over the years and also thank his close friends Bob Wedekind and Daryl Kohlhoff for their support as well. A private gathering of family and friends to celebrate Terry’s life will take place at a later date. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family.

item.title: Keith Howard Hanke
item.content:encoded:
Keith Howard Hanke, 53, of Baraboo, passed away unexpectedly on Thursday, Feb. 18, 2016 at his residence. Keith was born on Feb. 5, 1963 in Janesville, the son of Ralph and Delorice (Gsell) Hanke. He was a 1981 graduate of Baraboo High School. Keith was an assistant manager at Pizza Hut restaurants for over 30 years. In his spare time, Keith enjoyed playing darts, shooting pool and bowling. He was an avid Minnesota Vikings fan and a member of New Life Community Advent Christian Church in Baraboo. Keith especially enjoyed visiting with family and friends and will be dearly missed by everyone who knew him. Survivors include his mother, Delorice Hanke of Baraboo; a brother and sister, Kevin and Sue Hanke of Baraboo; three nephews, Nathan (Nikki) Hanke, Aaron (Erin) Hanke, and Chad (Beckey) Hanke; one great niece, Makailia; five great nephews, Skylar, Hunter, Blade, Keegan and Axel; and several cousins; other relatives and friends. Keith was preceded in death by his father, Ralph; his maternal grandparents, Howard and Olwen Gsell; his paternal grandparents, Ralph Sr. and Eliza Hanke. Memorial services will be held at 5 p.m. on Saturday, Feb. 27, 2016 at New Life Community Advent Christian Church, 1919 Elizabeth St., Baraboo, with Pastor Jed Crouse officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 3 p.m. until time of service. In addition, a benefit to celebrate Keith's life will take place at Poor Richard's, 411 Oak St., Baraboo, on Saturday, April 9, 2016 starting at 11 a.m. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.
