item.title: Ben Roe Barton
item.content:encoded:
Poynette - Ben Roe Barton, 74, of Poynette, passed away on Thursday, Dec. 10, 2015 at St. Clare Hospital in Baraboo. Ben was born on April 28, 1941 in Poynette, the son of Clive and Florence (Truan) Barton. On Nov. 14, 1959 he married Carol Ann Purdy in Portage. She preceded him in death on Nov. 2, 2010. Ben enjoyed tinkering with automobiles, attending stock-car races, doing crossword puzzles and fishing. He especially enjoyed being with family and will be dearly missed by all who knew him. Survivors include three children, Vicki (Cory Schutz) Auck of Poynette, Todd (Tammy Taylor) Barton of New Lisbon, Hilbert “Leo” (Dawn) Barton of Reedsburg; 20 grandchildren; 27 great-grandchildren; a sister, Loretta (Bill) McDonald of Baraboo; a brother, Gilbert (Charlotte) Barton of Baraboo; and several nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents and wife, Ben was preceded in death by a son, Ben Barton Jr.; daughter, Sheila Barton–Hughes; grandson, Jason Bertram; great-grandson, Harlee Peters; three sisters, Grace McInnis, MaryIda Barton and Betsy Weitzel; and a son-inlaw, LeRoy Auck. A celebration of life service will take place at 2 p.m. on Wednesday, Dec. 16, 2015 at Trinity Baptist Church, 53205 Golf Course Rd., Reedsburg, with Pastor Michael Lopp officiating. Survivors include her five children, Vicki (Jay) Seaman of Milwaukee, Debra (Don Carroll) Staton, Jeffrey (Jamie) Brescia and Kristine Craker all of Baraboo, Richard (Angela Haas) Brescia of Mauston; 12 grandchildren, David, Danny and Morgan Smith, Taylor Mills, Lacey, Nick and Tanner Craker, Dakota Hass, Kayley, Skyylar, Austen and Jenna Brescia; two great- grandchildren, Lorelai and Graysen Smith; a brother, Randy Ott of Baraboo; and other relatives and friends. item.title: William C. "Shorty" Tanneberg, Jr.
item.content:encoded:
North Freedom - William C. “Shorty” Tanneberg, Jr., 76, of North Freedom, passed away unexpectedly on Monday, Nov. 23, 2015 at his residence. Bill was born on May 7, 1939 in Ashland, the son of Willam Sr. and Lucille (Schwiesow) Tanneberg. He was a graduate of Sauk Prairie High School where he was the State weightlifting champion in his class. Bill was a jack-of-all trades and in his early years began working as a merchant marine on the ore boats traveling the great lakes. He then found his true passion with iron working and was employed by the local unions on various projects in Wisconsin and throughout the United States. In his spare time, he had become an expert Blacksmith where he designed and fabricated metal art work. He also was an airplane pilot and began constructing his own plane from scratch in his garage. He was truly a unique person with a mechanical ability to create just about anything with metal and hard work. In addition, Bill was a member of several organizations which included, the Iron Worker’s Union Local 383, Ashland Masonic Lodge of the F & AM #1515, the Shriners, life member of EAA, and a member of the Living Hope Church in Baraboo. Survivors include a son, Clifford (Barbara) Retzlaff; daughter, Christine (Ken) Dietrich; grandson, Duane Dietrich; granddaughter, Maryann Dietrich; a brother, John (Kay) Tanneberg; two sisters, Maryanne (Gary) Leiser, Kim (Charles) Horton; and several nieces, nephews, cousins, other relatives and friends. Bill was preceded in death by his parents; his wife, Deanna Retzlaff; two sisters, Darlene Tisdale and Linda Rohr; and four brother in-laws. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, Dec. 1, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor David Bauman officiating. Visitation will be from 10 a.m. until time of services. Burial will take place in Sauk Prairie Cemetery in Prairie du Sac. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the Living Hope Church, S3963 Cty Rd BD, Baraboo, 53913. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home is assisting the family with arrangements.

<]]>

item.title: Everett R. Kopf
item.content:encoded:
Everett R. Kopf, 81, of Baraboo, died on Saturday, Nov. 7, 2015 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. While a stroke affected the last 2-1/2 years of his life, he continued to carry himself with dignity and amazing grace. Everett was born on Feb. 3, 1934 in Ableman (Rock Springs), Wisconsin into the loving care of Raymond and Josephine (Schara) Kopf. He married the love of his life, Elaine (Retzlaff) on September 11, 1954. He enjoyed his growing up years with three amazing siblings, LaVonne (Ray) Astle of Reedsburg, Duane (Virginia) of Baraboo and Francis (Billi) of Oregon, Wisconsin. He is preceded in death by his parents, his sister, his niece, Sandy (Astle) Marselle and his in-laws George and Irene (Pickar) Retzlaff. He was blessed with four fun-loving children, Michael (Kathy) of Oshkosh, Randy of Baraboo, Brenda (Ron) Schultz of Baraboo, and Rebecca (Dana) Epperson of Rockford, Illinois. His children along with his wife comprised a close-knit family who were all with him until his death. Everett is survived by five grandchildren who adored him and couldn’t wait to spend time with him and the laughter that ensued when they all gathered: Ally (fiancé John Hodson) of Waukesha, Kari of Minneapolis, Mitchell of Denver, Robert (girlfriend Emilee Guderyon) of Madison and Josephine of Rockford. He also gained two bonus grandsons: Tyler Epperson of Tempe, Arizona and Andrew Epperson of Naperville, Illinois. His extended family also included seven nieces and nephews. After his family, Everett’s next love was his dairy farm – the same farm he grew up on and then purchased from his own father. His caring for all of God’s living creatures, whether human or animal, all received Everett’s amazing grace and attention. Everett also was a bricklayer for several years and helped create incredible buildings and churches during the course of his work. In addition to farming, Everett also enjoyed hunting, fishing, western movies, bowling, puzzles and traveling. His robust laughter could be heard rooms away, and his love of life and humble approach to help others before himself set him apart. He also was an active member of the Elks Club and Golden K. Everett’s family would like to especially thank those family and friends who visited him during his time at the nursing home and made an impact throughout his life. And special recognition and love is sent to all staff members of St. Clare Care Center who made Everett’s final years respectful and loved. A celebration of Everett’s life will be held with a visitation from 4 p.m. – 7 p.m. at St. Joseph’s Catholic Church, 300 Second Street, Baraboo, on Wednesday, November 11, 2015. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, November 12, 2015 with a visitation starting at 10 a.m. Fr. Jay Poster will be officiating. Interment will take place in Pleasant Valley Cemetery in Excelsior Township. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that memorials be made to St. Clare Care Center Activities Department, 1414 Jefferson St, Baraboo, WI 53913 or St. Joseph’s Catholic Church Basement Project, 300 Second Street, Baraboo, WI 53913. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. Take your well-earned angel wings and fly. Until we meet again, may you enjoy the comfort of God’s grace and love.

<]]>

item.title: John Stanko Jr.
item.content:encoded:
John Stanko Jr., 86, of Baraboo, passed away on Wednesday, Oct. 28, 2015 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center with his loving family by his side. John was born on March 25, 1929 in Chicago, Illinois, the son of John and Catherina (Stempak) Stanko. He attended Lane Technical High School in Chicago, and on July 16, 1949 he married Marilyn Ciesinski. She preceded him in death in 1984. He then married Leola “Lee” Ludeking in Northbrook, Illinois, on Nov. 2, 1985. John was employed as a supervisor electrician with the I.B.E.W. in Chicago and retired in 1992. In 1995, John and Lee moved to Baraboo where they made their permanent residence. He enjoyed skiing, dancing, traveling in the motorhome and wintering in Arizona at the Golden Vista RV Resort in Apache Junction. John especially enjoyed visiting with family and friends and was a member of the Baraboo Elks Lodge No.688 BPOE. Survivors include his wife of over 30 years, Leola “Lee” of Baraboo; his children, Karen (Rick) Silverman, Kenneth Stanko and Gail Kelly, all of California; four step-children, Shelley (Ringo) Lyzdius of Dubuque, Iowa, Robert Ludeking and Teresa (Michael) Bidwell, all of Wisconsin Dells, and Cindy (Christopher) Monson of Belleville; 15 grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, and several nieces, nephews, in-laws, and other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents and first wife, John was preceded in death by his son, Steven Stanko; two grandchildren, Shannon Voights and Krystin Bidwell; a brother, Michael Stanko; and a sister, Margaret Sremaniak. Memorial services will be held at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, Nov. 4, 2015 at the First Church of the Nazarene, 1800 Crawford St., Baraboo, with Pastor Jonathan Tipton officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 a.m. until time of service. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family would like to thank Dr. Thomas Rex Flygt and the staff at St. Clare Hospital and St. Clare Meadows Care Center for the wonderful care given to John during his stay. As John always said, “Cas jit domu”.

<]]>

item.title: Lawrence "Larry" S. Vroman
item.content:encoded:
Lawrence “Larry” S. Vroman, 74, of Baraboo, passed away on Saturday, Oct. 10, 2015 at St. Clare Hospital surrounded by his loving family. Larry was born on May 21, 1941, the second son of Gordon and Rosalie (Schoepp) Vroman. He was a 1959 graduate of Verona High School and on Aug. 31, 1963 Larry was united in marriage to Mary Grady in Sun Prairie. To that union was born three children; John, Jane and Joyce. Larry began his postal career in August of 1964 and retired after 36 years of service in December of 2000 as a superintendent of the Baraboo Post Office. He was a past Exalted Ruler of the Baraboo Elks Lodge No.688 BPOE, a member of the Knights of Columbus, and a faithful member of St. Joseph Catholic Church in Baraboo. He enjoyed spending time with his family, especially with his grandchildren. Survivors include his beloved wife of 52 years, Mary; three children; John (Christine) Vroman of Madison, Jane (David) Parchem of Baraboo and Joyce (Steve) Gehrmann of Sun Prairie; nine grandchildren, Anna, Katelyn, Nicole, Julia and Sarah Vroman, Jennifer, Jessica and Jayden Parchem, and Ben Gehrmann; two brothers, Lloyd and George (Chery) Vroman; a sister, Wanda (Tom) Marling; two brother-in-laws, David (Doris) Grady and Robert (Sandy) Grady; a special aunt, Jean Showers Nelson; and several nieces, nephews other relatives and many friends. He was preceded in death by his parents. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, Oct. 15, 2015 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, in Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will take place from 4 p.m. until 7 p.m. on Wednesday, Oct. 14, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home and at the church on Thursday from 10 a.m. until time of Mass. Interment will be held in St. Joseph Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials in memory of Larry may be given to the St. Joseph Annual fund. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Kathleen "Kay" (McMahon) Grady
item.content:encoded:
Kathleen “Kay” (McMahon) Grady, 94, of Baraboo, passed away on Saturday, Sept. 26, 2015 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. Kay was born on Oct. 20, 1920 in Endevor, the daughter of William and Fannie (Parrott) McMahon. She graduated from Montello High School and on Dec. 28, 1940 she was united in marriage to Joseph A. Grady at St. Mary’s Catholic Church in Portage. They made their home in Baraboo where Joe established the Grady Sewing Center in Baraboo. Kay was an active and supportive wife and mother. She enjoyed her volunteering work at St. Joseph Catholic Church, St. Clare Hospital Auxiliary and at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. Survivors include her son, Dennis (Marilyn) Grady of Pardeeville; a daughter, Jo Ann (Bill) Hoesly of Belleville; two grandchildren, Daniel and Kathleen and their families; a brother, Patrick Burke McMahon; and several nieces, nephews, other relatives and many dear friends. In addition to her parents and husband, Kay was preceded in death by a son, Gary; two brothers and one sister. Private family services will be held at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the St. Clare Meadows Care Center Activity Department. The family would like to thank Dr. Mathers for the years of compassionate care and acknowledge the staff and her friends at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Ruby Carol (Loomis) Mason
item.content:encoded:
Ruby Carol (Loomis) Mason, 91, of Baraboo, passed away on Friday, Sept. 25, 2015 at Our House Assisted Living in Baraboo. Ruby was born on Sept. 19, 1924 in Baraboo, the daughter of Daniel Ren Loomis and Effie Mariel Bartlett. She attended Baraboo schools and worked as a kitchen aid at West Elementary School. She had also been employed at several local businesses which included Servo Instrument Corp., Almet Manufacturing Co., and St. Clare Hospital. In her spare time, Ruby enjoyed dancing-especially to polka, reading and listening to music. She was a very positive, energetic person who enjoyed being around people and conversation. Family was especially important to her and she truly loved her many visits with family and friends. Survivors include her two daughters, Karen (Michael) Holverson of West Baraboo, and Judy Mason of Baraboo; a brother, James Mason of Rice Lake; and many grandchildren, great-grandchildren and great-great-grandchildren. Also surviving are several nieces, nephews, other relatives and a special friend, Ruth Hillebold. Ruby was preceded in death by her parents and her siblings. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home in Baraboo, with Luella Zipsie presiding. Visitation will take place from 10 am until time of services. Private interment will be held in Walnut Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the family. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Ruth (Helland) McGann
item.content:encoded:
Ruth (Helland) McGann, 101, of Baraboo, died on Friday, Sept. 4, 2015, at St. Clare Meadows Care Center with her loving family at her side. Ruth was born May 2, 1914 in Kilbourn, to Hans and Emma (Kittleson) Helland. She graduated from Wisconsin Dells High School in 1932. Ruth met the love of her life John “Jack” McGann and was married to him on June 6, 1936. They were extremely devoted to each other during their 63 years of marriage until Jack’s death on June 15, 1999. Together they raised two sons, Robert and James. Ruth enjoyed gardening, playing bridge, reading, golfing, and crocheting. Together, Jack and she frequently entertained family and friends. She was a tremendous cook and her grandchildren especially looked forward to her homemade applesauce, sugar cookies, and strawberry jam. Ruth and Jack loved to travel and were fortunate to winter in Pompano Beach, Florida, for close to 30 years. Ruth was a longtime member of the First United Methodist Church in Baraboo. In addition, she was a member of the Baraboo Country Club and a board member and volunteer at St. Mary’s Ringling Manor. Surviving her are daughter-in-laws, Nancy McGann of Baraboo and Johanna McGann of Merrimac; grandchildren, Casey (Jane), Bryan (Julia), Mike (Carrie), Mary and Shelly McGann, Darin Klemm, and Shelby Shirley; great-grandchildren, Sarah, Sean, Mitch, Maddy and Luke McGann, Jacob and Joshua Shirley; great-great-grandson, Jackson McGann; and many nieces and nephews. In addition to her parents and husband, those who precede her in death include sons, Robert and James; sisters, Gertrude Belton and Alice Helland; grandson, Mark McGann; and a great- granddaughter, Amanda McGann. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, Sept. 10, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, Baraboo, with Rev. Marianne Cotter officiating. Visitation will take place from 10 a.m. until time of service. Interment will be held in Walnut Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials in Ruth’s name can be made to the St. Clare Meadows Care Center Activity Department, First United Methodist Church, or the Baraboo Public Library. The family would like to express their deepest gratitude to the staff at St. Clare Meadows Care Center and Dr. Sharilyn Munneke for their loving care of Ruth. Also, a special thank you to Nancy McNamara who always left grandma looking so beautiful. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Gordon Raymond Glorch Sr. and Ann L. Glorch
item.content:encoded:
Naples, FL. / Baraboo, WI. - Gordon Raymond Glorch, Sr., 84, of Naples Florida, formerly of Baraboo, passed away on Saturday, Aug. 8, 2015 and joined his beloved wife, Ann Loppacker Glorch, who preceded him in death on June 13, 2015. Gordon was born in Chicago, Illinois on Nov. 14, 1930 the son of Raymond A. and Gertrude (Hanson) Glorch. Gordon proudly served in the United States Navy during the Korean War on the U.S.S. Wisconsin and was honorably discharged. He received a BS degree from Northwestern University and after running another company, purchased a division of Gulf and Western in Baraboo. He re-named the company, Servo Instrument Corporation in 1971 and remained President/CEO until his passing. Gordon leaves behind his children, Sally Ann Glorch, Susann (David) Elieff, Gordon (Roseli) Glorch, Jr.; grandchildren, Ann (Brian Montgomery), Mandie (John Kinniburgh), Samuel Elieff, Daniel Elieff, Mayra Souza; and two great-grandchildren, Jack and Jordan Kinniburgh. In addition to his loving wife, Ann; and his parents, Raymond A. and Gertrude Glorch; Gordon was preceded in death by a sister, Joyce Hull; and a brother, Raymond Glorch. Funeral services for Gordon and Ann will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday, Aug. 29, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home in Baraboo. Visitation will take place from 10:30 a.m. until time of services. Private interment will be held in Oak Hill Cemetery in North Freedom with military rites provided by the VFW Greenwood Memorial Post 987. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be sent in Gordon’s and Ann’s name to the Neighborhood Health Clinic of Naple, 121 Goodlette Road North, Naples, FL. 34102. Neighborhoodhealthclinic.org. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Patricia "Patty" A. Linkowski
item.content:encoded:
Patricia “Patty” A. Linkowski, 56, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully on Friday, Aug. 14, 2015. Patty was born on Oct. 16, 1958 in Chicago, Illinois the daughter of Donald and Ruth Hatton. Survivors include three daughters, Deanna Zinkie, Andrea (Nick) Ringelstetter and Erica (Shaun) DeSimone, all of Baraboo; seven grandchildren, Miranda Zinkie, Adrianna Cone, Mia and Cameron Ringelstetter, Makayla, Spencer and Treyton DeSimone; a brother, Donald (Ava) Hatton of Romeoville, Illinois; two sisters, Cathy Carlisle of Jasper, Alabama and Sandra (Mark Powers) Hatton of Burbank, Illinois. item.title: Denise Marie Radke
item.content:encoded:
Rock Springs - Denise Marie Radke, 63, of Rock Springs, passed away unexpectedly on Monday, June 29, 2015 at her home. Denise was born on March 12, 1952 in Chicago, Illinois, the daughter of James and Pearl (Dombrosky) Pedersen. She lived in La Valle and Baraboo before moving to Rock Springs in 1981. Denise worked at Land’s End and was active in many civic organizations, most recently serving on the Rock Springs Library Board. She participated in many area craft shows displaying her hand woven wool textiles and wooden walking sticks. Denise touched the lives of many with her generosity of spirit and trademark wit. She had an insatiable curiosity and was blessed with the ingenuity to turn the ordinary into the extraordinary. Above all else, Denise valued her family and friends, and respected and beautified the earth with her masterful gardening skills. She will be dearly missed by all who knew and loved her. Survivors include her four sons and their families, Paul (Michelle) Schwanbeck and their sons, Dillon and Jeremy, Mark (Yvette) Schwanbeck and their daughters, Brianna and Brooke, John (Raquel) Schwanbeck and their sons, Mason and Isaac, and James Radke; a brother, Jim (Georgia) Pedersen; and in-laws, Joe and Jane Soto; along with countless friends and family whom were blessed to know her. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Dieter E. Radke. Friends and family are invited to attend a memorial service at 12 p.m. noon on Sunday, July 5, 2015 at Our Savior Lutheran Church, 1120 Draper St., Baraboo, with Pastor David Jensen officiating. There will also be a Celebration of Life party on September 5, 2015 at 12 p.m. noon at the family farm. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Rock Springs Public Library. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Vera Mae Scoles
item.content:encoded:
Vera Mae Scoles, 85, of Baraboo, passed away suddenly on Sunday, June 21, 2015. Born on March 23, 1930 to Loranz and Martha (Redmann) Klein in North Freedom, Vera grew up on a family dairy farm there and was very active in Rural Youth. She was Valedictorian of Baraboo High School, Class of 1947. Vera worked as the radio dispatcher with the Sauk County Sheriff’s Department for the next 10 years, where she met patrolman Henry “Hank” Scoles. They married on November 3, 1956. Although Vera loved working at the Sauk County Sheriff’s Department, she left that career to start another –raising the four children with which she and Henry were blessed. Vera was a talented woman who wore many hats: 4-H leader, bookkeeper for Redigas, and later, Max Klein Industries, newspaper columnist for the Home News (Plain-Spring Green), crafter who sold her wares at area craft shows as well as stores in Baraboo, and devoted wife, partner, mother and grandmother. She found much joy in gardening and home preservation of the food she grew. She enjoyed traveling, most recently with her partner, Jerome Thiessen, attending classic car and aviation conventions. Vera was a long-time member of St. John’s Lutheran Church in Baraboo. In addition to Jerome, Vera is survived by her family, Alan Scoles of Wichita, Kansas, Karen (Jeff) Raizen of Denver, Colorado, Janet (Vincent) Nadile, of Tarrytown, New York, Linda (Mark) Edington, of St. Helens, Oregon; ten grandchildren, Zachary, Nathaniel “Hank” (Christine Chan), and Adina (John Rot) Raizen, Jacqueline, Victoria and Henry Nadile, Alexander, Anna, Samantha, and Nicholas Edington; many nieces, nephews, cousins and other relatives and friends. She was preceded in death by her parents, Loranz and Martha Klein; her husband of 42 years, Henry Scoles; and her brother, Herbert Klein. Funeral services will be held at 10 a.m. on Saturday, June 27, 2015, at St. John’s Lutheran Church, 624 East St., Baraboo, with Rev. Nick Maglietto officiating. Visitation will take place on Friday, June 26, 2015 from 4:30 to 7 p.m. at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo. Interment will be held in Oak Hill Cemetery, North Freedom. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be directed in Vera’s memory to the St. John’s Radio/TV Fund, or the Carbone Cancer Center UW.

item.title: Robert "Bob" W. Tully
item.content:encoded:
Robert “Bob” W. Tully, 85, of Baraboo, passed away on Saturday, June 13, 2015 at St. Clare Hospice House in Baraboo. Robert was born on Jan. 25, 1930 in Wauwatosa, the son of Richard and Elsie (Buxbaum) Tully. He grew up with an older sister, Lenore, and extended family that included his Tully grandmother, four uncles, five aunts, and five cousins. Most of these relatives resided within walking distance of his home. More distant clan members lived on outlying farms and in places close enough to visit on Sunday afternoon drives. His Buxbaum relatives lived in Milwaukee. This larger family provided wonderful role-models and a procession of interesting characters to enrich his childhood. Bob attended Wauwatosa schools and Lawrence University, where he received a joint degree from the Chicago Theological Seminary and University of Chicago Divinity School. He was ordained by the United Church of Christ in 1955. He began his service as Associate Minister of Central Congregational Church in Topeka, Kan., when he met the bright, perky church secretary, a Londoner named Vi Hare. She quickly became the love of his life and the two were married in April of 1958 at Vi’s home church in London’s East End. Together, they settled into the parsonage of Hope United Church of Christ in Sturgeon Bay for an 11 year pastorate and the birth of their three sons. The family them moved-on for a 24 year pastorate at First Congregational United Church of Christ in Watertown. Both of these congregations built new facilities during his years of Service. Upon retirement in 1993, Bob and Vi settled in Baraboo and did volunteer work. This included helping briefly at the International Crane Foundation and Circus World Museum, volunteering for over 12 years at St. Clare Hospital in Day Surgery, and devoting eighteen summers to greeting visitors every Friday at the Nature Center in Devil’s Lake State Park. In addition, Bob was one of the founders of Friends of Devil’s Lake and was an avid foe of invasive plants. Bob was a member of First Congregational UCC, Baraboo, and his interests included reading, hiking, gardening, travel and picking-up litter. Survivors include his wife, Vi of Baraboo; sons, Steven (Pat) Tully of Waterloo, Mark Tully of Baraboo, and John Tully of Viroqua; grandchildren, Kyla of Chicago, Ill., and Ian of Galesburg, Ill.; great-grandson, Devin, and great-granddaughter, Liliana; step-grandchild, Vanessa Morales of Waterloo; niece, Barbara Wolfe; nephew, Thom Wolfe; cousin, Marilyn (Bob) Olson; and other relatives and friends. Memorial services will take place at 2 p.m. on Sunday, June 28, 2015 at the First Congregational United Church of Christ, 131 6th Ave., Baraboo, with Pastor Douglas Fauth officiating. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. Memorials in honor of Bob may be given to; First Congregational United Church of Christ, Baraboo, the Wisconsin Council of the Blind and Visually Impaired, 754 Williamson St., Madison, WI. 53703 or you may pick-up litter anywhere you see it.

item.title: Erland R. Marg
item.content:encoded:
Wisconsin Dells - Erland R. Marg, 78, of Wisconsin Dells, passed away on Friday, June 12, 2015 at St. Mary’s Hospital in Madison. Erland was born on Jan. 26, 1937, in Granton, the son of Elmer and Agnes (Garbisch) Marg. He was a 1955 graduate of of Granton High School and attended the University of Wisconsin Platteville where he received a B.S. degree in Agriculture Education and Biological Science in 1959. On July 6, 1957, he married Dorothy Joyce Wallace at the First Lutheran Church in Platteville. She preceded him in death on June 7, 2003. He then married Jeanne Elsa Strackbein on May 14, 2005 at St. John’s Evangelical Church in Rock Springs. Erland worked at Waupaca Foundry as a Lab Manager for over 21 years before retiring. After retirement, he worked part-time at Christmas Mtn. mowing the golf course. In his spare time, he enjoyed the outdoors with traveling and camping. He was a member of St. John’s Evangelical Lutheran Church in Rock Springs, and served in the Wisconsin National Guard for over 37 years which included time during the Berlin crisis. Survivors include his wife, Jeanne of Wisconsin Dells; his ten children, Vicki, Steven (Linda), Kevin (Deborah), Michael (Michelle), Jeffrey (Lisa), Timothy (Sheila), Gary, Richard, Robert (Jodi), and Kim (Shayne) Pues; two step-children, Paula (Bruce Henke) Lins and Steven (Tanya) Strackbein; 21 grandchildren; seven great-grandchildren; two sisters, Alene Lautenbach and Amber (Harvey) Pischer; a sister-in-law, Rhoena Marg; and numerous other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents and first wife, Erland was preceded in death by two brothers, Curtiss and Duane; an infant sister, Ruth; daughter-in-law, Theresa Marg; brother-in-law, Ralph Lautenbach; and a sister-in-law, Gladys Marg. Honorary services will be held at 8:45 a.m. on Sunday, June 28, 2015 at St. John’s Evangelical Lutheran Church, 299 W. Broadway St., Rock Springs, with Pastor David Karow officiating. Inurnment will take place in Central Wisconsin Veterans Memorial Cemetery, King, on Friday, July 17, 2015 at 2:30 p.m. with military honors provided. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the church. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Ruth Clair Kennedy
item.content:encoded:
Ruth Clair Kennedy, 86, of Baraboo, passed away on Wednesday, June 10, 2015 at St. Clare Hospice House in Baraboo. Ruth was born on Aug. 7, 1928 in Camden, N.J., the daughter of Robert and Martha (Helsengreen) Hagen. On Dec. 2, 1950, she was united in marriage to James Francis Kennedy. He preceded her in death on May 9, 2003. In 1969, Ruth and Jim moved their family to Fond du Lac, WI., and then to Belvidere, Ill. in 1977. After Jim’s passing, Ruth then moved to Baraboo in 2004. Ruth enjoyed crafts and painting and loved making gifts for her family. She especially loved spending time with her many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Survivors include her children, Kathleen Luedtke of Plover, James (Maggie) Kennedy Jr. of Plantation, FL., Robert (Lori) Kennedy of Onalaska, WI., Margaret (Cory) Ruefer of Baraboo, WI., and Elizabeth (Scott) Busch of Dickeyville, WI.; 15 grandchildren; 10 great-grandchildren; and several nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. In addition to her parents and husband, Ruth was preceded in death by a son, Thomas; a daughter, Maureen; a great-granddaughter, Liberty; and a sister, Christine Farrell. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11 a.m. on Friday, June 19, 2015 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 304 East St., Baraboo, with Father Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church on Friday from 10 a.m. until time of Mass. Burial will be held in St. James Catholic Cemetery in Belvidere, Ill. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family would like to thank the staff at St. Clare Hospice House for the excellent care given to Ruth during her stay.

item.title: David Dean Caflisch
item.content:encoded:
David Dean Caflisch, 71, of Baraboo, died on Wednesday, June 10, 2015. He was born on Nov. 25, 1943 in Baraboo to Dean and Caryl (Colby) Caflisch of Sauk City. He claimed Kathryn Platt as his bride on Jan. 3, 1970. He was an expert mechanic and owner of Caflisch Auto and Truck Repair and Caflisch Recycling . Dave was active in many organizations which included Ducks Unlimited for over 55 years; Knights of Columbus, and the Elks. He was very proud of his accomplishment of securing funding for the Wautoma Legacy Marsh Project including 102 greenwings. He was a member of St. Joseph’s parish and was instrumental in parish festival activities which he did for over 30 years. He was also involved in several other charitable activities throughout the community. Dave is survived by his wife of 45 years, Kathryn; his son, David John; his daughter, Carol and her husband, Roy Georgeson; his grandchildren, Breanna and Zach Stilson, Logan, Tyler and Cassie Georgeson, and Hailey Caflisch; great- grandchildren, Annabelle and David Stilson; sisters, Ellen and Ivy Wartzok, Deanna and Frank Haselwander; nieces, Melody Walsh, Julie Wartzok, Sandra (Jeff) Weinke, Peggy Jo (Jim) Brown, Donna Hitchcock, Tamara Seiler; nephews, Oscar Wartzok, Jon (Kathy) Caflisch Jr. and Clint (Kathy) Caflisch. Also surviving are many great nieces and great nephews, great-great nieces and great-great nephews; special friends, Nicolette Zimmerman, Becky, Alek and Maddie Katcher, Chauncey, Bridgette and Abby Tierney; and numerous cousins and friends. He was preceded in death by his parents, Dean and Caryl Caflisch, John and Agnes Platt; a brother, Jon Caflisch; granddaughter, Mercedes Caflisch; and daughter-in-law, Marianna Caflisch. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, June 16, 2015 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will take place on Monday, June 15, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m. with an Elks Memorial service at 6:30 p.m. Continued visitation will be at the church on Tuesday from 10 a.m. until time of service. Burial will be held in Rock Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to Duck Unlimited or St. Josephs School Tuition Assistance Fund would be very appreciated.

item.title: James "Jim" L. Wareham
item.content:encoded:
James “Jim” L. Wareham, 64, of Baraboo, passed away on Monday, May 18, 2015 at St. Clare Hospital after a courageous battle with cancer, with his loving wife Linda by his side. Jim was born on June 16, 1950 in Baraboo, the son of Robert and Virginia (McNaughton) Wareham. He was a 1968 graduate of Baraboo High School and enlisted into the United States Air Force where he served his country during the Vietnam War. After being honorably discharged from the Air Force, Jim worked at the Badger Ordnance Ammunitions Plant in the front office. He then began a career with Thorp Financial in Madison and was eventually transferred to their office in Reedsburg where he met Linda Schulte. On Aug. 27, 1977 they were united in marriage at the Methodist Church in Reedsburg. Jim was an avid Wisconsin sports fan and loved to watch the Badgers and the Packers. He enjoyed the outdoors with camping, fishing and traveling throughout the country and abroad. He was a member of the VFW Greenwood Memorial Post 987. Survivors include his wife of 38 years, Linda of Baraboo; a sister, Noralee (Tom) Slezak of Maryland, and their two children, Scott and Christopher; sister-in-law, Nancy (Tom) Madland; brother-in-laws, Dennis (Claudia) Schulte of Reedsburg and William “Bill” (Wendy) Schulte of Junction City; and several nieces and nephew in-laws, other relatives and many friends. In addition to his parents and grandparents, Jim was preceded in death by his father-in-law and mother-in-law, Virgil and Ruth Peper-Schulte (Erv) Vollbrecht; and a uncle, Patrick T. McQuire. Memorial services will be held at 11:30 a.m. on Saturday, June 13, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor Thomas Dunbar officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home from 10:30 a.m. until time of service. Military honors will be provided by the VFW Greenwood Memorial Post 987. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the family. A luncheon reception will be held at Poor Richard’s Bar, 411 Oak St., Baraboo, immediately following the service.

<]]>

item.title: Bill (WH) Johnson
item.content:encoded:
Bill (WH) Johnson, of Baraboo, died unexpectedly at his home on Sunday morning, May 31, 2015. Bill was born in Chicago, Ill., the son of the late Oliver and Loraine (Gilmore) Johnson. He was united in marriage to Annette Hanger on Aug. 19 1995. Bill served in the U.S. Navy during the Korean Conflict as a Naval Aviator and achieved the rank of Lieutenant JG. He was employed with the Zenith Corporation for over 25 years. Bill enjoyed traveling, visiting with family and friends, but most of all spending time with his grandchildren. Survivors include his wife, Annette; children, Patricia (David) Thomas, Robert (Sylvia) Johnson, David (Pat) Johnson, Barbara Kahn; step-children, Josh (Misty) Hanger, Joseph (Anita) Hanger, Jason (Jessica) Hanger; grandchildren, Robert Jr. Johnson, Joshua and Sarah Thomas, Judy Ambrose, Tianda Deaver, Jamie, Jacob, John and Justin Hanger; great-grandchildren, Tiffany Ambrose, Sabrina Burgess and Caleb Johnson; extended family, Brian, Scott, Connie and John Dobush, and many other special friends . Funeral services will be held at 12 p.m. noon on Saturday, June 6, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor Karen Hofstad officiating. Visitation will take place from 11 am until time of services. Military rites will be performed by the Eagles Nest Detachment Marine Corps League.

item.title: John "Jack" G. Anstett
item.content:encoded:
Menomonee Falls - John “Jack” G. Anstett, age 87, of Menomonee Falls, formerly of Baraboo, passed away on Wednesday, April 29, 2015 at Community Memorial Hospital in Menomonee Falls. Jack was born on May 6, 1927 in Lake Lanore, Saskatchewan, Canada, the son of Fred and Mary Agnes (Devine) Anstett. He graduated from Baraboo High School in 1945 and joined the Merchant Marines. Jack then enlisted in the United States Navy where he served his country during WWII on the USS Zellars DD-777. He was a life member of the VFW and American Legion, and was a member of the Army ROTC at the University of North Dakota. Jack graduated from the University of North Dakota majoring in History, minoring in Physical Education and with a Bachelor of Philosophy degree. While at U.N.D, he met and married, Betty M. Zejdlik in 1952. Together, they had four children; Mark, Erin, Paul and Lyn. Betty preceded him in death in 1985. After college, Jack worked in the Group Department of New York Life at the Kansas City office. Later, he joined the newly formed Group Department of Wisconsin Physicians Services where he worked for over 20 years and retired as a Regional Group Manager. Jack then purchased an office building and tavern in Racine. On May 15, 1991, Jack married Sue Rizzo at St. Lucy’s Catholic Church in Racine. The two enjoyed their time traveling, golfing, going for walks, and Jack’s favorite past time, supporting his beloved Green Bay Packers. Jack was a season ticket holder of Lambeau Field for over 50 years. It was important for him to share the Lambeau experience to as many people as possible. He felt that every person should experience a Packer game at Lambeau Field at least once in their life. Jack had a love for history, reading, animals, and many other sports. Jack is survived by his wife, Sue; a son, Mark (JoAnn) Anstett; two daughters, Erin Anstett and Lyn (Steve) Steger; grandchildren, Taylor Steger, Jacqueline Cottingham; extended grandchildren, Kelly Zolin, Jacob Wisinski, Alex and Sam Rizzo, Anna and Noah Lawneczak; siblings, Roy Anstett of Tacoma, Wash., Arlene (Les) Pedersen of Kalamazoo, Mich., Jerry (Irene) Anstett of Stevens Point; sister-in-law, Edith Anstett of North Freedom; other extended relatives, Ann (Joe) Ceschin, Mary K. Wisinski, Fred (Elaine) Rizzo, Gina (Art) Lawnieczak and Paul Rizzo. Also surviving are many nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. Jack was preceded in death by his parents; first wife, Betty; a son, Paul; siblings, Chet, Fred, Emmett, Viola and Ralph Anstett; brother-in-law, Andy Nyquist; sisters-in-laws, Win, Jinine, Sally and Lil Anstett; granddaughter, Katie McQuestion; and beloved dog and buddy, Dutch Anstett. A Memorial Mass will be held at 10:30 a.m. on Saturday, May 16, 2015 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 304 East St., Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 9:30 a.m. until time of Mass. Military rites will be provided by the Baraboo Veterans Honor Guard. Private inurnment will take place in St. Joseph Cemetery at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the American Heart Association or the National Diabetes Association. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Thomas Fred Buelow
item.content:encoded:
Lyndon Station - Thomas Fred Buelow, 69, of Lyndon Station, passed away unexpectedly on Tuesday, April 14, 2015 at his residence. Thomas was born on Sept. 10, 1945 in Baraboo, the son of Norton and Dorothy (Stieve) Buelow. He attended Baraboo High School and on June 21, 1990 he was united in marriage to Trudy Meyer at St. John’s Lutheran Church in Baraboo. Thomas enlisted in the U.S. Navy in 1966 and served for two years before being honorably discharged. He was employed at Grede Foundry in the maintenance department for over 30 years. In his spare time, Thomas enjoyed the outdoors with hunting, fishing and teaching. He truly loved being around family and will be dearly missed by all who knew him. Survivors include his wife, Trudy of Lyndon Station; two sons, Todd (Tracy) Buelow and Shane (Sarah) Buelow, all of Baraboo; daughter, Robin Lainhart of Burlington, Ky.; six grandchildren, Sara, Rachael, Samantha, Jordan, Kyle and George; two brothers, Dennis (Sharon) Buelow and Charles (Juanita) Buelow, all of Baraboo. He was preceded in death by his parents and grandparents. Memorial services will be held at 11:30 a.m. on Friday, April 17, 2015 at the Rago- Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor Nick Maglietto officiating. Visitation will take place at the funeral home from 10 a.m. until time of service. Inurnment will be held in Walnut Hill Cemetery following the service. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Carolyn Sue LeRoy
item.content:encoded:
Carolyn Sue LeRoy, 69, of Baraboo, passed away on Wednesday, April 8, 2015 at St Clare Hospice House. Survivors include a daughter, Cindy (Greg) Blackley; two grandchildren, Jordan and Justin Schultz; a sister, Ruth (Jerry) Nolden; brother, Bill (Sandy) Harrison; and several nieces and nephews. item.title: Phyllis M. Hannon
item.content:encoded:
Denver, Colorado - Phyllis M. Hannon, 90, of Denver, Colo., formerly of Reedsburg, passed away on April 7, 2015 after a brief illness. She was born on August 20, 1924, in Baraboo, the second of five children born to Philip Leo and Ella Jane (Murphy) Hannon. She grew up on the family farm on Reedsburg Road. Phyllis left the Reedsburg area in her early twenties. She held numerous government jobs throughout her life some of which included; the Internal Revenue Service in Milwaukee, the Health Education and Welfare Department and the Public Health Service, in Washington, D.C., the Bureau of Land Management as Chief of Communications, and various other state jobs in Denver. Phyllis enjoyed her years out east and the education it provided working in the nation’s capital. It also offered her great opportunity to travel on the east coast which she found enlightening. She truly loved her years in Colorado and the lovely hikes in the mountains, ski jaunts, together with golfing and other outdoor sports, where she made many great friends. She was always a traveler and was able to visit extensively including; Alaska, Hawaii, and many other states, and throughout Europe and Mexico. She was especially fond of the time she got to spend in Ireland, Scotland, Wales and England. Christmas holidays were reserved for her family in Wisconsin. Always a lady who liked to stay busy, Phyllis was involved with numerous areas of volunteer work including the Red Cross, working at numerous hospitals, accompanying patients to sporting events, the Capitol Hill Community Center and with the Colorado Food Share Program. Her Irish heritage and catholic faith were very important to her. She was a very prayerful person and a great letter writer. Phyllis is survived by her sisters, Jane Brill of Houston, Texas, Rosemary Gunn of Janesville; and her brother, Rodney Hannon of Reedsburg. She will also be missed by her nieces and nephews, Patti Grosenick, Robert Brill, Mark Gunn, Mike Jurick, Barbara Hoskins, Maureen Hunter, Bernard Jurick and Mary Leonard. In addition to her parents, Phyllis was preceded in death by her sister, Joyce Jurick; brothers-in-law, Robert Jurick, Biddle Gunn and Everett “Red” Brill; and a niece, Kathy Jurick. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday, April 11, 2015 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 304 East St., Baraboo, with Father Jay Poster presiding. There will be a visitation at the church from 10 a.m. to the time of mass. Private burial will be held at a later date in St. Michael’s Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the church. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. May the hand of a friend always be near you, and may God fill your heart with gladness to cheer you. Happy Happy Merry Merry!

item.title: Patricia Joyce Lee
item.content:encoded:
Patricia Joyce Lee, 68, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully on Friday, March 27, 2015 after a long struggle with lymphoma with her loving husband by her side. Pat was born on Feb. 12, 1947 in Baraboo, the daughter of William R. and Joyce G. (Mortimer) Dummer. She attended Baraboo schools and on July 11, 1964 married the love of her life, Hank Wayne Lee. Together, they lived in Baraboo where they raised their two children, Lance and Stacie. Pat loved her family and the special memories shared together. She also enjoy going to the casino and the many vacation trips taken with Hank. Survivors include husband, Hank; son, Lance Lee; daughter, Stacie (Chuck Dickman) Loveluck; five grandchildren, Danielle (Eddie) Erickson, Nicole (Jeff Erickson) Loveluck, Jessica, Tanner and Andrew Lee; seven great-grandchildren, Eddie Jr, Ariana, Nevaeh, Donte, Nickoli, Aubrie and Livia; brother, William (Laurie) Dummer; brother-in-law and sister-in-laws, Bob (Nancy) Lee, Dick (Ruth) Lee, Jerry (Sharon) Lee, John (Melinda) Lee, Ron Lee, Maryann Lee, Gail Dobratz, Linda Niebhaber; and many nieces, nephews, cousins, and dear friends. In addition to her parents, Pat was preceded in death by a sister-in-law, Janice Lee; and her father-in-law and mother-in-law, Kenneth and Edith Lee. The family will be holding a celebration of life for Pat at a later date to be announced. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. “They say time heals all sorrow and helps us to forget, but time so far has only proved how much we miss you yet. God gave us strength to face it, courage to bear the blow. But what it meant to lose you, no one will ever know.” Sadly missed by her family.

item.title: Max Wilhelm Herrmann Sr.
item.content:encoded:
Max Wilhelm Herrmann Sr., 98, of Middleton, formerly of Baraboo, passed away peacefully on Friday, March 6, 2015 at Heritage Senior Assisted Living in Middleton. Max was born June 14, 1916 in Beloit, the son of Max Bernard and Ada Mae (Jenks) Herrmann. He graduated from Wauwatosa East High School and attended the University of Wisconsin-Madison where he was the yearbook editor in 1939. He enlisted in the Army Air Corps during WWII and was trained as a bombardier in a B-17 and served from 1941-1945, attaining the rank of First Lieutenant. On October 10, 1942 he married the love of his life, Ruth Louise Hampel in Topeka, Kan. After his honorable discharge from the service, they lived in Milwaukee, Elkhorn, Roseville, Minn., Hales Corners and finally, Baraboo. During the winter months of their retirement years, they traveled to their home in Venice, Fla. While living in Hales Corners, Max served on the Whitnall Area School Board and PTA when Whitnall High School was first built, and was also a founder and Deacon at Heritage Presbyterian Church. After working for several years in business management, he bought W.C. Heath and Associates, a well-respected consulting firm with offices on the top floor of the Milwaukee Gas Building, at that time the tallest building in the city. He later sold that business and moved to Baraboo to manage and then own Humane Equipment Company. During his time there, Max traveled to Germany and secured the technology and licensing to use recycled tires to manufacture cow mats and other related products and the company grew substantially. He served on the Sauk County Development Board and the Baraboo Community Development Association. In addition, Max and Ruth were members of the First Presbyterian Church. Max worked hard to provide a wonderful life for his family. He enjoyed spending time with his wife and two sons and especially the family vacations up North, out West to the Rocky Mountains and other areas. His other outside interests included gardening, yard work and having the best looking lawn and rose bushes in the neighborhood. While in Florida, Max and Ruth took up square and ballroom dancing and enjoyed beachcombing and swimming in their pool. They belonged to several bridge clubs over the years and always looked forward to a good game. Golf was Max’s favorite activity and to say he was an avid golfer would be an understatement. Max lived a full and abundant life, enjoying his many friends and family. His mind was sharp and his health was good until he passed, so he endured little pain or suffering. We will miss him dearly and like Ruth, he will be cherished in our hearts forever. Max is survived by his loving sons, Max III (Renee) and Jeffrey (Nan); grandchildren, Krista, Linnea (Chris) Mortensen, Stephanie; great-grandchildren, Madelyn and Ethan Mortensen; nieces, Emmy Lou (Herb) Jahn, Roberta (John) Cerniglia, Louise (Lyle) Anderson; nephews, George Hampel, Jr., Lance Hampel and John (Lynn) Hampel; and many other relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife of 71 years, Ruth; his parents; a brother, Karl; and his sister, Martha. Memorial services will be held at 1 p.m. on Tuesday, March 17, 2015 at the First Presbyterian Church, 416 Ash St., Baraboo, with Pastor Lisa Taylor officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 12 p.m. noon until time of service. Private interment will be held at a later date in Lincoln Memorial-Wanderers Rest Cemetery, Milwaukee. In lieu of flowers, memorials to the First Presbyterian Church are appreciated. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Gene "Pinky" David Higgins
item.content:encoded:
Gene “Pinky” David Higgins, 72, of Baraboo, was a man of dignity, bravery, and compassion, who passed away on the evening of Saturday, March 7, 2015 surrounded by his family. He was born on Jan. 6, 1943 in Baraboo, to John and Dahlia Higgins. Gene made an early name for himself as a second baseman for the 1958 Baraboo State Babe Ruth Champions. He was later inducted into the 2013 inaugural class of Baraboo’s Baseball Hall of Fame. Gene earned his Bachelor’s degree in Business Administration through the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and remained an avid Badger fan throughout his life. He had over 20 years of banking and trust management experience, followed by a career at the Projected Planning Company as a financial advisor who specialized in retirement income and investments. On April 6, 1974 he was united in marriage to Beverly Wendt in Baraboo. He proudly served in the U.S. Coast Guard and was very active in the Baraboo community serving various organizations including; the local Hope House, St. Clare Hospital, and the former Magdalene Home. Above all, Gene was a selfless man, fully devoted to Beverly Higgins, his wife of over 40 years, and to their child, Hillarie Higgins. He loved music, nature, and always prioritized his family and friends before him. Gene will be dearly missed by all. Survivors include his wife, Beverly; daughter, Hillarie (David); brother, James (Nancy); mother-in-law, Betty Wendt; and numerous nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, cousins, in-laws and wonderful friends. In addition to his parents and grandparents, Gene is now reunited with his sister, Shirley; uncle, Peter; father-in-law, Lester Wendt; two brother-in-laws, Dick Kaestner and Larry Wendt; and other cherished souls. A Memorial service will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday, March 21, 2015 at St. John’s Lutheran Church, 624 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor Carl Schroeder officiating. Visitation will take place at the church from 10 a.m. until the time service. Memorials to the family would be appreciated. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

Beulah Berdene Grant, 98, of Baraboo, passed away on Sunday, Feb. 22, 2015 at Maplewood of Sauk City. She was born on Jan. 14, 1917 in Sparta, the youngest of 13 children to Charles and Minnie (Stark) Morgan. In March of 1935, she married Clement Grant in the Little Brown Church in the Vale, Iowa. He preceded her in death in 1987. Beulah was employed as a nursing assistant in the OB department at St. Mary’s Ringling Hospital, and later at St. Clare Hospital. She retired after 26 years of service and many deliveries. She truly enjoyed visiting with family and friends and will be dearly missed by all who knew her. Beulah is survived by three children, Nancie (Joseph) Luce, and Nedra Grant, both of Baraboo, and Charles (Marsha) Grant of Spring Green; six grandchildren; eight great-grandchildren; and other relatives and friends. In addition to her parents and husband, she was preceded in death by her siblings. Private graveside services will be held in Walnut Hill Cemetery. item.title: Kathryn Louise (Amundson) Prosser
item.content:encoded:
Kathryn Louise (Amundson) Prosser, 83, of Baraboo, died Sunday, Feb. 22, 2015 at St. Clare Hospital. She was born May 22, 1931, to Helmer and Leone Amundson of Baraboo. Kay attended Baraboo High School and then went on to the University of Wisconsin-Madison. She graduated in 1953 with a degree in English education. On Dec. 27, 1954, she married John R. Prosser of Antigo. They lived in Madison, Neenah and Baraboo. They had seven children. Along with taking caring of her large family, Kay taught in Delavan, New Glarus, Baraboo, and for 20 years, Wisconsin Dells. One of the many highlights of her career was in 1985, when she received the “Wisconsin Creativity in Teaching Award.” She retired in 1991. beginning some adventurous travel with long-time friend, Marion Finger. Actively involved in St. Joseph Parish and school, which all her children attended, Kay held many roles. She had a myriad of interests from writing poetry to volunteering at Devil’s Lake. Her faith, her family, her grandchildren, reading, nature, traveling, her book club, water aerobics, the food pantry, the hospital rehab group, and education were all part of her active lifestyle. Kay was preceded in death by her husband, John; her sons, Gregory and Joseph; her parents, Helmer and Leone; her brothers, Allyn and Robert. Kay is survived by her five children, John (Annette) Prosser of Georgia, Michael (Sandra) Prosser of Franklin, Steven (Deb) Prosser of Oregon, Sarah (Bradley) Philabaum of Baraboo, Garth (Jeni) Prosser of Colorado. She is further survived by grandchildren, Peter (Marisa) Sky, Jake and Katy Philabaum, Heather (Clint) Eckstein, Nathan (Nikolle) Prosser, Nicholas (Brandy) Prosser and Holly (Chance) Prosser; many step-grandchildren; and a great-granddaughter, Bailey Prosser. Other survivors include her sister, Sue Ebert; brother, Jim Amundson; sisters-in-law, Jane Amundson, Nancy Ropella and Sally Hielsberg; and many cherished nieces; nephews; and friends. A Mass of Christian burial will be held at 11:30 a.m. Saturday, Feb. 28, 2015 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 304 East St., Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be held from 10 a.m. until the time of Mass at the church. Burial will take place in St. Joseph Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to St. Joseph’s Church, Friends of Devil’s Lake, Baraboo Food Pantry or to a charity of your choice. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Wendy Sue Meier

Wendy was born on Feb. 28, 1959 in Waukesha, the daughter of Henry and Agnes (Schade) Meier. Wendy lived her life to the fullest and made every day an adventure. item.title: Chad E. Schultz
item.content:encoded:
Chad E. Schultz, 35, of Baraboo, the beloved son of Carl and Gloria Schultz, passed away unexpectedly at his home on Tuesday, Feb. 17, 2015 from a pulmonary embolism. Chad was born in Baraboo on Oct. 3, 1979 and attended Baraboo schools. Chad always had a sparkle in his eye and his thoughtfulness revolved around Jesus, his family and friends. He was a faithful member of the Seventh Day Adventist Church. Chad was a talented artist who spent his time painting, drawing and sculpting. He was also a true outdoorsman who enjoyed hunting, fishing, and observing astronomy. Chad is lovingly remembered by his parents, Carl (Gloria) Schultz of Baraboo; a brother, Chris (Michelle) Schultz and their three children, Joey Schultz of Lubbock, Texas, Stephanie Schultz (fiance’ Tony Toarmina) of Saline, Mich., and Sgt. Matthew (Mandy) Schultz of Lawton, Okla.; and their three children, Nathaniel, Darrell and Gabriella, all of Lawton, Okla.; a sister, Cylinda (Josh) Shepard and their two children, Carson and Kallie Shepard, all of Sun Prairie. The family would like to thank Aunt and Uncle, Edward (Suzanne) Strampe, Sr., for their unconditional love and support given to Chad throughout the years, and to Aunt, Janice Strampe for her generosity. Special thank you to Derek (Crystal) Allard for their friendship, loyalty and support they have shared with Chad. He will be greatly missed by all his family, aunts, uncles, cousins, friends and his two devoted dogs, Rocko and Pepper. He was preceded in death by his grandparents. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Saturday, Feb. 21, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo. Visitation will be at the funeral home from 10 a.m. until time of service. item.title: Michael A. Van Slyke
item.content:encoded:
Sauk City - Michael A. Van Slyke, 56, of Sauk City passed away on Tuesday, Feb. 10, 2015 at St. Mary’s Hospital in Madison. Michael was born on Aug. 25, 1958 in a U.S. Army Hospital in Germany, the son of Ralph and Eunice “Susie” Van Slyke. He was a 1977 graduate of Sauk Prairie High School. Michael was an avid sportsman who enjoyed fishing, hunting, and traveling throughout the United States. He participated in numerous Mountain Man rendezvous events where he dressed in buckskin, started fires with flint and steel, and threw tomahawks. His greatest love was his family with whom he created many special memories. He was a devoted father and grandfather. His witty sense of humor will be missed by all. Survivors include a daughter, Linde (Kenny) Van Slyke; three grandchildren, Ivy, Violet and Vladimir; three sisters, Laurie (Rick) Wenger, Mary (Dan) Forcier, Sandy Van Slyke; a brother, David Van Slyke; his mother, Eunice “Susie” Van Slyke; and several nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by his father, Ralph; and his grandparents. A celebration of Michael’s life will be held at 11 a.m. on Friday, Feb. 20, 2015 at Walnut Hill Bible Church, 1900 East St., Baraboo, with Pastor David Hutchens officiating. Visitation will take place at the church from 10 a.m. until time of service. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Marian Emma Getsinger
item.content:encoded:
Marian Emma Getsinger, 98, of Baraboo, passed away Wednesday, Jan. 14, 2015, with her family members at her bedside at Oak Park Place. Marian was born in Pittsville, March 23, 1916 to Verne and Elsa McCoy. She attended grade and high school in Pittsville, later attended a two-year county college in Wisconsin Rapids. Later in her teaching career, she received a bachelor’s degree in upper elementary education from the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point. Marian taught for 23 years in Wisconsin public schools, serving her last 17 in Baraboo, where she taught middle school math. Many of her students still living in the community remember her as a tough but fair educator. She met her husband, Henry Getsinger, while teaching in Cranmoor. They married in Crown Point, Ind., in October 1937. While Henry served in the Pacific during World War II, Marian moved to Wautoma to live with her parents and sister until her husband returned. The couple moved to Baraboo in 1948, where they raised two children, Stephen and Sandra. A devoted neighbor, Marian could often be found delivering a homemade pie, bread or cookies to a friend in need. She was a longtime member of First United Methodist Church, although illness recently made it impossible for her to attend services. An avid reader, Marian was fascinated by history and sought to understand the deep-rooted connections driving the world around her. She was a cutthroat Scrabble player with a vibrant vocabulary. A declining mental status made some aspects of her life very difficult in her last years, but Marian’s deep faith remained a source of comfort and strength, even to her last days. Though sassy at times, Marian’s greatest gift was her ability to see the goodness inside each person. She will be deeply missed by those who loved her. Marian was preceded in death by her husband of 30 years, Henry; and her sisters, Helen Danielson and Eileen Dilts. She is survived by her son, Stephen (Ruth) Getsinger, of Baraboo; a daughter, Sandra (Robert) Pizzola, of Lafayette, Ind.; grandchildren, Annie and Elizabeth Getsinger, Katie (Chad) Albertson, Matthew and David Pizzola; and three great-grandchildren. A celebration of life service will be held at 10 a.m. on Saturday, April 25, 2015 at the First United Methodist Church, 615 Broadway St., Baraboo, with Pastor Marianne Cotter officiating. Visitation will be from 9:30 a.m. until time of service. Private inurnment will be held in Forest Hill Cemetery, Wisconsin Rapids. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the First United Methodist Church. Her family would like to extend a sincere thank you to the dedicated staff of Oak Park Place’s Autumn Lane memory unit, Drs. James R. Damos and Stuart G. Hannah, and Agrace Hospice for the kind, compassionate care shown to Marian. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home is assisting the family with arrangements.

<]]>

item.title: Delores Jean (Paske) Schultz
item.content:encoded:
Delores Jean (Paske) Schultz, 81, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully on Friday, Jan. 2, 2015. She was born on Nov. 15, 1933 in the Township of Caledonia, the daughter of August and Clara (Schueler) Paske. Delores married Russell Schultz in 1957 and he preceded her in death on April 18, 1991. In her younger years, she worked at the Lodi canning factory and after marrying Russell, Delores became a full time homemaker. She enjoyed sewing, reading, collecting recipes and articles, cooking, baking and gardening. Delores was an excellent canner and every summer she canned many fruits and vegetables. She liked flowers and when she planted a garden, it would include several different varieties. Delores especially enjoyed spending time with her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Survivors include her sons, Kenneth Schultz and Brian Schultz; her daughter, Debra (James) Fawcett; four grandchildren, Darren (Sheila) Ringelstetter, David (Jackie) Ringelstetter, Ashley Schultz and Meghan Schultz; three great-grandchildren, Justin, Jacob and Emmett Ringelstetter; sister, Marion Johnson; and many nieces and nephews. In addition to parents and husband, Delores was preceded in death by three brothers, Raymond, Arnold and infant, Kenneth Paske; and two sisters, Esther Geymann and Gladys Thompson. A special thanks to her son, Brian, for his devotion, love, and care giving for all the years he was there for her. Per Delores’s wishes, the family will hold a private service at a later date. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

<]]>

item.title: Joseph Edward Dietenberger
item.content:encoded:
North Freedom - Joseph Edward Dietenberger, age 73, of North Freedom, passed away on Thursday, January 1, 2015 at Maplewood Nursing Home in Sauk City. Joseph was born on Dec. 14, 1941 in Hartford, the son of Edward Martin and Lucille (Sharph) Dietenberger. He was a graduate of Hartford Union High School and received a B.S. degree from U.W. Stout, and his masters from U.W. Madison. On Aug. 8, 1964 he was united in marriage to Beverly Prahl at St. Joseph Catholic Church in Baraboo. Joseph was an Industrial Technology and Driver’s Ed teacher for Ashwaubenon School District for over 36 years. He retired in 1999 and moved to North Freedom. During his teaching career he also coached cross country and youth soccer. During his retirement, he became active in the Sauk County Salvation Army. He enjoyed the outdoors with hunting, fishing and spending time on his rural property. In addition to his wife, Beverly of North Freedom, he is survived by his three children, Susan (Dave) Teska of Baraboo, Ronald (Lisa) Dietenberger of Germantown and Jerrad (Anna) Dietenberger of Rochester, Minn.; six grandchildren, Lizzie, Claire, Katherine, Alissa, Edward and Andrew; two brothers, Jack (Louise) Dietenberger, Gene (Marianne) Dietenberger; two sisters, Mary (Darnell) Wagner, Carol Montag; and several nieces, nephews, other relatives, and friends. Joseph was preceded in death by his parents and a brother-in-law, Hubert Montag. Memorial services will be held at 11 a.m. on Friday, January 9, 2015 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, with Fr. Garrett Kau officiating. Visitation will be held from 10 a.m. until time of service. Private inurnment will take place in Rock Hill Cemetery, Baraboo Township.

item.title: Madeline "Madge" Mary Buzzell
item.content:encoded:
Madeline “Madge” Mary Buzzell, 89, of Baraboo, passed away on Wednesday, Dec. 3, 2014 at St Clare Meadows Care Center. Madeline, the daughter of Victor and Mary (Juris) Ligneel, was born on April 13, 1925 in Lodi. After graduating high school, Madeline attended St. Mary’s School of Nursing and received a certificate in nursing. She began her nursing career at Gisholt Manufacturing, in Madison, as an Industrial Nurse. While there, she met and married Harry Buzzell on Aug. 3, 1955. Together they lived in North Freedom where Madeline began working at St. Mary’s Ringling Hospital in Baraboo. After the transition from St. Mary’s to St. Clare Hospital, Madeline retired after 34 years of service. She was a long-time member of St. Joseph Catholic Church. Survivors include two daughters, Caryl (Richard) Pfaff of Baraboo and Barbara (Richard) Wagner of Barrington, Ill., six grandchildren; six great-grandchildren; a sister, Marion Buchanan of Lodi; and many nieces; nephews; other relatives and friends. In addition to her parents and husband, she was preceded in death by, a son, Darwin Buzzell; a grandson; one brother; and four sisters. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Monday, Dec. 8, 2014 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 304 East St., in Baraboo, with Fr. Garrett Kau officiating. Visitation will be at the church on Monday from 10 a.m. until time of service. Burial will take place in Oak Hill Cemetery in North Freedom. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to St. Joseph Catholic Church or St. Clare Hospital. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Nicole "Niki" Jean Hause
item.content:encoded:
West Allis - Nicole “Niki” Jean Hause, 32, of West Allis, formerly of Baraboo, passed away unexpectedly on Sunday, Nov. 30, 2014 at her home. Niki was born on Nov. 23 1982 in Baraboo, the daughter of Steven and Justine (Nikl) Hause. She was a stay at home mother who lived for her two children, Lilus, 11, and Tony, 8. Niki was a fun loving and giving person who loved to laugh, dance and be with people. Her tenacious pursuit of fun will always be remembered by her family and friends. Survivors include her children, Lilus and Tony; her partner, Tony Lopez of West Allis; her parents, Steven and Barbi Hause of Baraboo, Justine “ Tina “ Nikl and Gil Leija of Beloit; two brothers, Jeremy (Kari Baker) Hause and Zachary Campbell; a sister, Jori Hause, all of Baraboo; grandparents, Ed Nikl of Hampstead, N.C., and Dee Hinds of Baraboo; a niece and nephew, Brianna and Gregg Hause of Baraboo; several aunts, uncles, cousins, other relatives and close lifelong friends. Niki was preceded in death by her grandparents, William and Lillian Hause, Marlys Nikl and Robert Hinds. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place at 11 a.m. on Friday, Dec. 5, 2014 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 304 East St., in Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be held at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, from 5 p.m. to 7 p.m. on Thursday, Dec. 4, 2014 and at the church on Friday from 10 a.m. until time of Mass. A private family burial will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the family for the benefit of Niki’s two children.

item.title: Jennifer "Jenny" Jane Eddy
item.content:encoded:
Reedsburg - Jennifer “Jenny” Jane Eddy, 78, of Reedsburg, died Tuesday, Nov. 11, 2014 at the Reedsburg Area Senior Life Center. She was born in Evanston, Ill., on Oct. 2, 1935, the daughter of Josephine (Stauding) and Howard Eddy. A lifelong educator, she received her B.A., B.S., and M.S. degrees from Bemidji State University, Bemidji Minn. from 1957 to 1962, majoring in Chemistry and Biology. She also took advanced courses from the University of Wisconsin Superior and the University of Minnesota and received two N.S.F. grants for summer course work at Kansas State College and Oregon State University. Jenny began her teaching career at the Mazeppa Minnesota High School from 1958-1960. She taught Chemistry at Bemidji State University from 1960-1964, and at University of Wisconsin Stevens Point from 1964-65. She continued at the University of Wisconsin Green Bay from 1965-69 and at UW Baraboo/Sauk County from 1969 until her retirement in1997. During her years at UWGB, Jenny was very active in women’s athletics being both a tenacious team mate and coach in both basketball and softball. She patiently guided a group of independent basketball players into a cohesive team that successfully competed in both recreational and AAU competitions During her career at UW Baraboo/Sauk County, Jenny was recognized with three “Teacher of the Year” awards. Devoted to her students, she successfully prepared them for advanced courses and their careers, patiently working with those who needed extra help. Many alumni still talk fondly about their learning experiences with “Miss Eddy” and remember her black Labrador Snoopy accompanying her in the 1970’s. She is also remembered as the very capable umpire for the iconic Codger Brat softball game which is still held each spring. Jenny had a profound interest in nature, visiting natural areas and national parks across the nation, and enjoyed traveling by canoe in wilderness areas. Growing up in northern Minnesota, she enjoyed hiking in the woods, canoeing, and fishing. She was an accomplished photographer, producing a significant body of work with an emphasis on flowers, birds and nature. She gifted her photo collection to the UW-Baraboo/Sauk County library where it is being digitized. She was also a noteworthy artist working in the mediums of serigraphy, pen and ink as well as wood and ceramics. Jenny is survived by her brother, Joe Eddy; and many nieces, nephews and special friends. She was preceded in death by her parents, Josephine and Howard Eddy; and her brothers, Howard “Jim” Eddy Jr.; and Charles “Chuck” Eddy. Per her wishes, there will be no services. Memorial donations may be given to the Jenny Eddy Nursing Scholarship, the Chemistry Department, or the T.N. Savides Library, at Friends of the Campus, Inc., UW Baraboo/Sauk County, 1006 Connie Rd, Baraboo, WI. 53913. The Rago Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Irma Helen Lange
item.content:encoded:
Irma Helen Lange, 94, of Baraboo, passed away Monday, Nov. 3, 2014 at St. Clare Hospital. Irma was born Sept. 15, 1920 in Fountain Prairie Township, Columbia County, the daughter of LeRoy and Adeline (Sekel) Weidemann. On August 10, 1940, she married Edward Lange, and they celebrated 52 years of marriage. He preceded her in death on Nov. 5, 1992. She graduated from the Zion Lutheran School, Columbus High School and Columbia County Teacher College. She continued earning her teaching credits through the University of Wisconsin. She taught elementary grades in Columbia and Sauk Counties for twelve years and in St. John’s Lutheran School, Baraboo, for seven years. Irma enjoyed arts and crafts, reading, crossword puzzles, playing cards and bowling. She was a member of St. John’s Ev. Lutheran Church, Ladies Aid and Division C for over 50 years. She was also an honored member of the Wisconsin Retired Educators Assoc., Sauk County Retired Educators Assoc., and Baraboo Women’s Club. Survivors include her two daughters, Laural (Del) Mineard of Sun Prairie, Suzanne (Jim) Dohner of Baraboo; four grandchildren, Jess (Ellie) Dohner of Madison, Shelley (Jeff) Crabb of Indianapolis, IN., Kevin (Kristie) Mineard of Franklin, Jennifer (Brian) Albrecht of Baraboo; and seven great-grandchildren, Elizabeth and Davidson Dohner, Kendall and Keagan Mineard, and Jackob, Lukas, and Katelynn Albrecht. Funeral services are at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, Nov. 5, 2014 at St. John’s Ev. Lutheran Church, 624 East St., in Baraboo, with Pastor Nick Maglietto officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 am until time of service. Burial will be at Walnut Hill Cemetery. Memorials may be given, in her name, to St. John’s Ladies Aid Scholarship Fund. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Warren "Lou" Luther Bidwell
item.content:encoded:
Warren “Lou” Luther Bidwell, 84, of Baraboo, passed away peacefully at St. Clare Hospital on Saturday, Nov. 1, 2014 surrounded by his loving family. Warren was born on July 4, 1930 in Cooperstown, ND., the son of Baxter and Hazel (Knight) Bidwell. He was a veteran of the United States Army and served his country during the Korean War. On Feb. 2, 1952 Warren was united in marriage to Helen Florence Hanson. They celebrated 43 years together and raised five children. Helen preceded him in death on Sept. 4, 1995. On Oct. 22, 2005, Warren married Mary L. Ketchum. They just celebrated their 9th wedding anniversary. Over the years, Warren worked several jobs including the Baraboo News Republic, the Post Office, and Adesa Auto Auction House. He was very active in the community and served as alderman for the City of Baraboo for many years. He was also a member of the Elks Lodge #688, the American Legion Post #26, and the Church of the Nazarene. In his spare time, Warren loved to travel. He enjoyed road trips and time spent with family. He especially looked forward to Bidwell family reunions, where they donned cowboy hats and boots, guitars and harmonicas and sang along to all the old family favorites. He also enjoyed Hanson family reunions in Vernon County and visits with Lynn and Terry Nelson. Warren was dearly loved and will be missed by many. Survivors include his wife, Mary of Baraboo; five children, Bryan (Susan) Bidwell of Madison, Michael (Teresa) Bidwell of Wisconsin Dells, Mark (Doreen) Bidwell of New Market, Ala., Dawn (John) Meegan of Baraboo, Lisa (Dan) Reilly of Portage; nine grandchildren, Jacob (Cara) Bidwell, Stacy (Marvin) Bynum, Rebecca Bidwell, Megan (Paul) Brandon, Molly (Brent) Davis, Sadie Meegan, Lydia and Seth Reilly; seven great-grandchildren, Hazel, Moses, Miles, Mercer, Carter, Mason, Kate; four sisters, Irene Walter, Ilah Lee, Betty Ann Simon, June PaDelford; step-son, Bruce Smith; step-grandchildren, Almanzo and Melissa Cronn; step-great grandson, Xavier. Also surviving are in-laws, Mardell (Reginald) Briggs, Shirley Hanson; and many nieces, nephews other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents and first wife, Warren was preceded in death by three sisters, Laura Glum, Oren Stull, Doris Bitz; three brothers, George Bidwell, Donald Bidwell, and infant, John; a granddaughter, Krystin Bidwell; three step-children, Scott, Yvonne and Ricky Smith. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Thursday, Nov. 6, 2014 at Church of the Nazarene, 1800 Crawford St., Baraboo, with Pastor Jonathan Tipton officiating. Visitation will take place at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., Baraboo, on Wednesday, Nov. 5, 2014 from 4 to 7 p.m., and at the church on Thursday from 10 a.m. until the time of service. Burial will be held in Walnut Hill Cemetery with military graveside rites provided by the Baraboo Veterans Honor Guard. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the Baraboo Food Pantry.

Myers, Fla., and Linda Ramsey of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.; four nephews; two nieces; eleven great nephews and nieces; and his precious cat, Calico. item.title: Martin Mendez Sr.
item.content:encoded:
Martin Mendez Sr., 68, of Baraboo, passed away after a brief battle with cancer on Friday, Oct. 3, 2014 at St. Mary’s Hospital in Madison. Martin was born on April 28, 1946 in Crystal City, Texas, the son of Indelecio and Amada (Gomez) Mendez. On Sept. 24, 1966, he was united in marriage to Shirley Zeis at St. Thomas Catholic Church in Waterford. Martin worked for the State of Wisconsin at the Southern Wisconsin Center in Racine County for over 30 years. In his spare time, he was a taxidermist and also enjoyed artwork and carving. Survivors include his loving wife, Shirley; two children, Mona Rae Mendez of Almond and Marty (Sharon) Mendez Jr. of Lyndon Station; two grandchildren, Meghan and Maxwell Mendez; a sister, Anita Mendoza of Dallas, Texas; and several aunts, uncles, nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his parents, a brother, Frank Mendez; and two sisters, Belia Flores and Santa Tores. item.title: Brian C. Geick
item.content:encoded:
Brian C. Geick, 27, of Baraboo, went to his heavenly home on Tuesday, Sept. 16, 2014 following a valiant four year battle with leukemia. Born in Milwaukee, to Ed and Cherie (Laureys) Geick, he grew-up in Illinois, Iowa and Wisconsin. Brian was an avid sports enthusiast and enjoyed running, water skiing, scuba diving and football in particular. He received his Bachelor’s Degree from the University of Wisconsin Madison and majored in marketing. He was a member of the Beta Epsilon Chapter of the Kappa Sigma Fraternity at UW-Madison. Brian is survived by his mother and father; a sister, Laura; his great aunt, Barbara Campbell; and many uncles, aunts and cousins in Illinois and Wisconsin. Brian also has many friends from high school, college, work and his many adventures. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, Sept. 20, 2014 starting at 2 pm at his parent’s house in Baraboo. In lieu of flowers, please consider donating to the Leukemia Research Foundation or American Cancer Society in Brian’s name to help find a cure for this disease. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Mary C. McGregor

Mary C. McGregor, 86, of Baraboo, passed away on Monday, Sept. 15, 2014 at St. Clare Hospital. Mary was born on Aug. 6, 1927 in La Crosse, the daughter of Charles and Mae (Hampton) Poole.
