In her spare time, she enjoyed playing bridge and knitting. She is survived by her husband of 66 years, Delbert “Del” McGregor; two children, Sara McGregor of Platteville, and Tom (Anita Gallucci) McGregor of Madison; three grandchildren, Sam and Ben Kleefisch, and Liana McGregor; and a circle of close friends. item.title: Monroe "Chub" Charles Hein
item.content:encoded:
Monroe “Chub” Charles Hein, age 89, of Baraboo, passed away on Thursday, Aug. 28, 2014 at Oak Park Place in Baraboo. Monroe was born on June 22, 1925, in the Township of Merrimac, the son of James Monroe and Clara Anna Maybel (Schnieder) Hein. In 1945, Monroe was united in marriage to Dawn A. Stearns in Merrill. She preceded him in death in 1994. He then married June Ellen Westcott on April 4, 1998 at the First Presbyterian Church in Baraboo. She preceded him in death in December of 2008. Monroe was a Veteran of WWII, serving his country in the United States Army Air Force as a rear gunner with the 303rd Heavy Bomber Squadron. In his civilian life, he was employed for over 30 years as a carpenter superintendent with Marshall-Erdman Associates Construction Corp., in Madison. In his spare time, Chub enjoyed the outdoors and was an avid fisherman. He was a member of St. Paul’s Lutheran Church in Baraboo, and a member of the VFW Greenwood Memorial Post 987. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Survivors include two daughters, Sherry (James) Gawronski of Plymouth, Ind., and Cindy DeRusso of Wisconsin Dells; four grandsons; four granddaughters; 10 great- grandchildren; a sister, Estella Stevens, of Baraboo; two cousins, Keith (Sue) Hein of Beloit, and Doris (Edward) Gamroth of Eau Claire; and other relatives and friends. In addition to his parents and wives, Monroe was preceded in death by two brothers, Donald and James; three sisters, Viola, Virginia and Lorraine; and a sister-in-law, Betty. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, Sept. 2, 2014 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, with Pastor Karen Hofstad officiating. Visitation will take place from 10 am until time of service. Interment will be held in Oak Hill Cemetery, in Merrimac, with military graveside rites provided by the VFW Greenwood Memorial Post 987. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to Oak Park Place.

item.title: Ronald "Ron" Ostrander
item.content:encoded:
Ronald “Ron” Ostrander, age 76, of Baraboo, passed away on Saturday, Aug. 23, 2014 at Agrace HospiceCare in Fitchberg. Ron was born on May 15, 1938 in Monroe, the son of Claude and Gladys (Burrington) Ostrander. He attended Baraboo High School and then enlisted in the United States Navy, where he served his country from 1956 to 1960. On Oct. 4, 1984 he was united in marriage to Marion Trittin in LasVegas, Nev. Ron was a meat cutter at Jefferson Meats, in Jefferson, for over 20 years and at Oscar Meyer Food Corp., in Madison, for over 7 years before retiring. In his spare time, he enjoyed boating on the Mississippi river and was a life-long member of the Edwin Frohmader VFW Post 1879 in Fort Atkinson. Ron also served as their bar manager for several years at the post. Survivors include his wife, Marion, of Baraboo; a daughter, Renee (Mike) Engelhart of Jefferson; a son, Jimmy Lee (Letycia) Barnes of Florida; two brothers, Duane of Portage and Gene of Baltimore, Md., five grandchildren; six great-grandchildren; several nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. Ron was preceded in death by his parents; two sons, Mark and Brion; and a step-son, Randolph Miller. A celebration of Ronald’s life is being planned for a later date. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, is assisting the family with arrangements.

<]]>

item.title: Joseph Wisinger
item.content:encoded:
Joseph “Joe” Wisinger, 83, of Baraboo, passed away on Sunday, June 1, 2014 at Maplewood of Sauk City Nursing Home. Joe was born on March 3, 1931 in Sendehely, Hungary, the son of Jakob and Maria (German) Wirschinger. In 1946, at the age of 14 he went to Germany to seek work as a farm hand and coal miner. While there, he met Fannie Forster and they were married in 1951. Their first daughter Angie was born, and in 1952 they immigrated to the United States. They were graciously sponsored by a Wisconsin farm family near Rice Lake and while there, Joe learned farming and daughter Carol was born. Later, Joe moved the family to Lead, S.D., and in 1954, he enlisted in the United States Army as part of an artillery unit during the Korean War. Afterwards, Joe joined the National Guard unit and was also employed by the Homestake Gold Mining Corporation, working deep underground. Then, Laura, Roger and Steve were born and Joe enjoyed taking the whole family on numerous hunting and fishing excursions. In 1967, Joe brought the family to North Freedom, and he worked for several area companies including the Badger Army Ordinance Ammunitions Plant where he was in production for many years. After production stopped, Joe stayed on and worked in maintenance learning the painting trade and became a union painter. During seasonal layoffs, Joe donated his time and expertise to St. Joseph Catholic Church, in Baraboo, where he completed countless beautiful projects that he was very proud of. He also travelled the United States working on a variety of projects ranging from a nuclear power facility in Texas to a road side motel in California. In retirement, Joe could not take the harsh Wisconsin winters so he decided to settle in Paradise, Calif., where he could indulge in a unique gold panning hobby. In 2009, he came back to Wisconsin and lived his remaining years in comfort, near his family, and believing his time to meet the lord would come soon. That day came last Sunday morning when he passed in peace to meet the Lord. Joe is survived by his five children, Angie (Rick) Scott of Black Earth, Carol (Phil) Denzer of North Freedom, Laura Waddell of McFarland, Roger (Julie) Wisinger of Oregon, and Steve Wisinger of North Freedom; seven grandchildren; three great-grandchildren; and former spouse, Fannie Wisinger of Baraboo. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by several brothers and sisters. Private Funeral Services will be held at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo. Interment will take place in Walnut Hill Cemetery with military honors provided by the VFW Greenwood Memorial Post 987. “Our Dad was a very kind, gentle and giving man, we will miss him, we will never forget him, and we will always love him.”

<]]>

item.title: Nita Joanne (Sanders) Dippel
item.content:encoded:
Nita Joanne (Sanders) Dippel, 83, of Baraboo, died peacefully in the comfort of her home after a courageous eight month battle with cancer surrounded by her beloved family. Her Heavenly Father welcomed her home on the morning of Friday, June 6, 2014. She was born on Jan. 16, 1931, in Rockford, Ill., the only child of Roy Herbert Sanders and Loveta Marie ‘Billie’ (Hooper) Sanders Bright. Nita was a loving daughter, grand-daughter, step-daughter, and a devoted wife, mother, daughter-in-law, grandmother, great-grandmother and friend. She met the love of her life, Al Dippel, while attending Baraboo High School. Following graduation in 1949 she returned to Rockford and was employed as a secretary. Nita was united in marriage to Albert R. Dippel, Jr. on June 24, 1951 at Trinity Lutheran Church, Rockford. Following Al’s overseas tour of duty in the United States Army, they lived in Stoughton, and Chicago, Ill., returning to Baraboo in 1958, where Al became a partner in the C. P. A. firm of Hoppe, Fishkin, Dippel, & McNevin. Al and Nita’s union was blessed with the birth of four sons; Roger Bryan, Robert Roland, Richard John, and Ross Albert. They welcomed her grandmother, Anna Belle Sanders of Rockford, into their home in 1960. Nita was very active in the Baraboo community. A member and former Elder of The First Presbyterian Church, she sang in the choir for a number of years, was a Den Mother, and directed a number of plays presented at the church. A Life member of Baraboo Theatre Guiild, she served in many capacities, directed a number of the Guild’s productions, and portrayed “Mama Rose” in the Guild’s first musical, Gypsy, presented in 1967. She was a past member and officer of the Order of the Eastern Star, and co-wrote and directed the Star Pageant presented to an audience of 400 at the Annual State Convention in Milwaukee. In 1961 the State Jaycette Organization approached Nita to start an Auxiliary for the Baraboo Jaycees. She served a two-year term as the first President, was honored to be presented with the State Jaycette Citation and Recognition for Outstanding Leadership Award, and the local chapters Life Membership Award. She served with St. Clare’s Hospital Auxiliary for a number of years as a board member, co-chaired the first Hospital Charity Ball, and in 1972 Nita was commissioned by the local Sisters to write and direct a pageant celebrating the Centennial of the Order of the Sisters of St. Mary. Serving as Auxiliary President in 1976 she was actively involved with the spectacular St. Clare’s Liberty Bell Ball. She served as a director on the Baraboo Bi-Centen-nial Committee, planning the cities celebration for the Nation’s 200th Birthday, organizing the year’s activities, writing the script for the July 4th Pageant, and portrayed Kate Smith at the close of the festivities. In 1973 Nita became very active in the Wisconsin Theatre Association which represented Community, Professional, Secondary, and University Theatres throughout the state. She filled many positions on its board for 14 years. In April of 1990 she received the Wisconsin Theatre Association Annual Life Service Award for Outstanding Service to Theatre in Wisconsin. Over a 16 year period she was one of only three High School Drama Directors to receive this award. In 1982 Baraboo held a yearlong celebration for its’ Centennial. Nita was one of the three chairs for this project of pageants, parades, shows, big cakes and celebrations. Nita accepted the position of Drama Director at Baraboo Senior High School in 1980. Throughout the next 10 years, in addition to 20 mainstage productions, plays were prepared for the annual State One-Act Play Festival. Individual students earned acting awards at this festival, and in 1985, Nita and Choreographer, David SaLoutos received an Outstanding Directors Award. Through hard work and dedication, student David Baxter, was awarded the $10,000 Liberace Acting Scholarship to Marquette University. In later years she acted as a theatre consultant, and a free-lance director for area community theatres. In the fall of 2013, Nita was named to the Wisconsin High School Forensic Association Hall of Fame. One of the highlights of her theatrical career was directing Baraboo Theatre Guild’s 40th Anniversary production of The King and I. Al and she felt deeply honored to receive the Kiwanis Club’s Dr. Al Dippel Community Service Award in 2001. For many years Nita had been interested in her family genealogy, and became a recognized member of the Daughters of the American Revolution, Fay Robinson Chapter, Reedsburg, in 2003. She was a member of the Des Plaines, Ill., Geneva, Ill. Beverly, Mass., and Sauk County Historical Societies, and many other national historical organizations. Following years of research and documentation of the diaries and Civil War letters of her great-great grandfather, she began writing the story of his life and times. Her love of family and history kept her working on this project until the time of her death. Following their retirement Al and Nita enjoyed traveling over 100,000 miles in their motor home, appreciating our unique country, and doing historical research. She was preceded in death by her father, Roy, 1946; her mother, ‘Billie’, 1973; her beloved Grandmother, Anna Belle Sanders, who died at the age of 108 in 1984; and her step-father of 41 years, Robert Bright, 1987; other family members and dear friends. Nita is survived by her loving husband of 62 years, Al; her sons and daughters-in-love, Roger (Lena), Baraboo, Robert (Karma), New Glarus, Richard (Karen), South St. Paul, Minn., and Ross (Christine), Sturgeon Bay; six grand-daughters, Heather Marie (Justin) Marlette, Baraboo, Annalee (Hackie) Warrensford, Marlborough, Mass., Elizabeth Anna, Allison Lydia, Rebecca Mary, South St. Paul, Minn., Isabella Christianne, Sturgeon Bay; and great-grandchildren, Miliani Kate Marlette of Baraboo, and Oliver Raymond Warrensford of Marlborough, Mass.; two step-great-grandchildren, Randi and Dalton; a step-grandaughter, Kari (Jason) Fritz; and step-great-grandsons, Riley and Dylan, New Glarus; and step-grandson, Chris O’Connor, Phoenix, Ariz. She is also survived by her sister-in-law, Evelyn (Gilbert) Lloyd; and a niece, Annette Lloyd, all of Niagara On the Lake, Ontario, Canada; her deeply cherished friend of many years, Lorraine Kindschi, Baraboo; a very special niece and nephew, Helen and David Wessel, Willmington, Ill.; the very dear and much loved members of her extended family, including Pat Reis, Camp Douglas, and David and Linda Atkins, Prairie Du Sac; a number of cousins, and many friends and former students. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, June 11, 2014 at the First Presbyterian Church, 416 Ash St., in Baraboo, with Pastor Lisa Taylor officiating. Visitation will take place on Tuesday, at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, from 4 to 7 p.m. and at the church on Wednesday from 10 am until time of service. Interment will follow in Walnut Hill Cemetery. Memorials may be made to the First Presbyterian Church or the Baraboo Senior High Theatre Department. Nita loved her family and treasured their summer camping trips together. She felt deeply blessed by her extended family and friends, and delighted in theatre, family antiques, books, crafts, music, needlework, and travel. A project person, she always had one in progress, including creating over 40 family picture albums. Enjoying life to the fullest, she often quoted Emily from Thornton Wilder’s play, Our Town; “It goes so fast. We don’t have time to look at one another. ----- Oh earth, you’re just too wonderful for anyone to realize you! Do any human beings ever realize life while they live it - every, every minute?”

<]]>

item.title: Stase Semenas
item.content:encoded:
Stase Semenas, 97, of Baraboo, passed away on Saturday, May 31, 2014 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center just two weeks short of her 98th birthday. She was born in Irkutsk, Siberia on June 12, 1916 the daughter of Zdislovas and Elena (Bartkus) Lapas. Raised in her native Lithuania, Stase found her life changed often by war and circumstance. She became adept at making a new life, first in London, then Germany and Chicago, and finally, when macular degeneration made it difficult to live alone, in Baraboo. She worked in Chicago for Draugas Lithuanian Newspaper, Carson Pirie Scott and Company, and Balzekas Museum of Lithuanian Culture. Stase was an enthusiastic world traveler, and touched all the continents except Antarctica. Her greatest love however was her three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Survivors include her daughter, Nijole Etzwiler and beloved son-in-law, David, of Baraboo; grandchildren, Chris (Angie) Etzwiler of Des Plaines, Ill., Peter (Elise) Etzweiler and Michael Etzwiler of Baraboo; great-grandchildren, Andrew, Eric, Valerie and Zoe; sister-in-law, Grazina Lapas of Toronto, Canada; niece, Rita (Peter) Cary of New Hampshire; nephews, Rick (Daiva) Lapas of Toronto, Canada, Raymond (Ramune) Lapas and Thomas (Laurie) Lapas of Chicago, Ill., George (Nijole) Gaucys of Seattle, Wash.; and dear traveling companion, Vera Scoles of Baraboo. In addition to her parents and husband, Alfonsas, she was preceded in death by brothers, Viktor, Edward and Haris Lapas; and sisters-in-law, Vilhelmina and Emilija. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 12 p.m. Noon on Wednesday, June 4, 2014 at St. Joseph Catholic Church, 304 East St., in Baraboo, with Fr. Jay Poster officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 11 a.m. until time of Mass. In lieu of flowers, Stase would be happy to know that memorials are made to: Draugas at http://www.draugas.org/ or Sunlight Orphan Aid at http://www.sunlightorphanaid.org/ or Child’s Gate to Learning http://childgate.org/. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. Words cannot fully express the family’s gratitude to the aides and nurses at St. Clare Meadows for the gentle and loving care they gave Stase for the three years she lived there.

item.title: Betty Jane Thomas
item.content:encoded:
Betty J. Thomas, 91, of Baraboo, passed away on Friday, May 16, 2014 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. Betty was born on Dec. 25, 1922 in Cleveland, Ohio, the daughter of Donald B. and Beatrice (Hull) Lyons. She was a 1940 graduate of Glenville High School and worked for the Detroit Steel Company of Cleveland for 25 years. On Sept. 4, 1971 she married Roy H. Thomas in Mentor, Ohio, after meeting on a trip to Mexico. They enjoyed their many travels together prior to his death on Feb. 13, 1993. After moving to Baraboo in 1971, Betty was a secretary to the director of the Circus World Museum for over 11 years. She had been a member of the Sauk County Humane Society, the Inter Se Club, and an active member of the First United Methodist Church in Baraboo. Survivors include a cousin, Sharon Naylor of Cleveland, Ohio; and many wonderful friends in Baraboo. In addition to her parents and husband, Betty was preceded in death by her brother, Robert. Per Betty’s wishes, no services will be held. Memorials can be made to the Sauk County Humane Society. Betty loved all of her animals, especially her Airedale dogs. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family would like to thank Dr. Randy Krszjzaniek and the staff at St. Clare Meadows Care Center for the wonderful care given to Betty.

<]]>

item.title: Buda Mary Powell
item.content:encoded:
Buda Mary Powell, 92, of Baraboo, passed away on Thursday, May 15, 2014 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. Buda was born on Aug. 24, 1921 in Fairfield, Township, the daughter of Herbert and Verne (Porter) Thomas. She attended Leach Creek School and graduated from Baraboo High School in 1940. On Oct. 25, 1947 she was united in marriage to Floyd Powell in Wausau. He preceded her in death in January of 1994. Buda was a homemaker most of her life and also had worked part-time at Industrial Coils in Baraboo. She was a volunteer at St. Clare Meadows Care Center, taught Sunday school at Baraboo Assembly of God, made quilts for missionaries and enjoyed reading a good book. Survivors include her three children, Sue (Dennis) Melvin of Sun Prairie, Mary (Wesley) Knight of Dalton and Colleen (Russell) Austin of Janesville; 12 grandchildren; 20 great- grandchildren; a sister-in-law, Betty Thomas of Baraboo; special friends, Roxanne (David) Biffert and their family; and many nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. In addition to her husband, Floyd, and her parents, Buda was preceded in death by her brothers, Donald, Roy and Carl; her sisters, Audrey and Doris; and a great-grand daughter. Funeral services will be held at 3 p.m. on Sunday, May 18, 2014 at One Life Assembly, 1000 11th St., in Baraboo, with Pastor Jon W. Arneson officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 2 p.m. until time of services. Interment will take place in Fairfield Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the One Life Assembly Church or Assembly of God U.S. Missions. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family would like to thank the staff at St. Clare Meadows Care Center for the wonderful care given to Buda during her stay.

item.title: Hazel Irene Romberg
item.content:encoded:
Hazel Irene Romberg, 87, of Baraboo, passed away on Sunday, May 4, 2014 at St. Clare Meadows Care Center. Hazel was born on March 15, 1927, in Winnipeg Manatoba, Canada, the daughter of John and Leah (Spark) Currie. On Sept. 20, 1950, she was united in marriage to Howard A. Romberg at Calvary Temple in Winnipeg Manatoba, Canada. She was a pastor’s wife, following Howard to North Dakota where she served for over 40 years in the North Dakota District Council of the Assembly of God. Hazel was very involved in all aspects of being a pastor’s wife and enjoyed the challenges and friendships that came with the title. Her door was always open for family and friends to come and visit. In August of 1992, she and Howard retired and moved to Baraboo. Hazel was an exceptional cook and seamstress, and especially enjoyed quality time spent with her children and grandchildren. She also enjoyed traveling throughout the United States. Survivors include her husband, Howard of Baraboo; son, Lyndon (Carolyn) Romberg of Eagan, Minn.; daughter, Sherri (Vince) Martens of Baraboo; five grandchildren, Miche’le Cortinas, Jennifer Ketterling, Jordan Romberg, Melissa and Timothy Martens; three great-grandchildren, Jamison Cortinas, Lane Ketterling and Noah Martens; two brothers, Gordon and Loyd Currie; and other relatives and friends. In addition to her parents, Hazel was preceded in death by two brothers, George and Clifford Currie; a sister, Anna May Wiens; and two infant granddaughters. Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Friday, May 9, 2014 at One Life Assembly, 1000 11th St., in Baraboo, with Pastor Jon Arneson officiating. Visitation will be at the church from 10 a.m. until the time of services. Interment will take place in Walnut Hill Cemetery. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements.

item.title: Gary "Pops" Styles
item.content:encoded:
Gary “Pops” Styles, 60, of Baraboo, passed away on Tuesday, April 29, 2014 at his residence. Gary was born on Jan. 30, 1954 in Detroit, Mich., the son of the late Charles and Shirley (Smith) Styles. On March 16, 2007 he married Tammy Morgan in Baraboo. Gary had been employed as a supervisor at Teel Plastics for over nine years. In his spare time he enjoyed fishing, camping, riding his motorcycle and visiting with family and friends. In addition to his wife, Tammy of Baraboo, he is survived by a step-son, Donald Turnmire of Wisconsin Dells; two sons, Keith (Jennifer) Styles of North Carolina and Kris (Christine) Styles of Michigan; grandson, Gunner Styles of North Carolina; a brother and sister, Danny (Teri) Styles and Kathy Styles, both of Michigan; and many friends. Gary was preceded in death by his parents and grandparents. A Memorial service will take place at 12:30 p.m. on Saturday, May 10, 2014 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, with Pastor Randy Zeman officiating. Visitation will be held from 11 a.m. until time of service. In lieu of flowers, memorials in honor of Gary may be given to the family.

<]]>

item.title: Philip "Phil" Franklin Niles
item.content:encoded:
Philip “Phil” Franklin Niles, 72, of Baraboo, passed away from cancer at the St. Clare Hospice House on Friday, April 25, 2014. Philip, the son of John and Helen (Nuzum) Niles, was born on Dec. 29, 1941 in Baraboo. He was a 1960 graduate of Baraboo High School and on April 22, 1995 he married Susan Hiller in Baraboo. Phil worked for the Sauk County Sheriff’s Department for over 21 years and retired as a detective. He had also been employed at St. Clare Center, managed the school bus company, and spent his last 13 years working in security at Ho-Chunk Casino. Phil always had a ready smile and enjoyed greeting and visiting with the people at the casino. He retired from the casino in 2007. In addition, Phil worked part-time as a driver for Classic Limousine, did lawn maintenance in the neighborhood, and numerous odd jobs throughout the summer season. Phil so loved and enjoyed his little grandsons, Drake age 6, and Garrett age 3, as they loved riding in the cart behind his lawn tractor. They looked forward to green grass and those rides around the neighborhood with grandpa. Phil also enjoyed time spent at the shooting range with his older grandson, Matthew, when visiting from Georgia. In addition to his devoted wife, Susan of Baraboo, Phil is survived by four children, Lynn Graham of Dawsonville, Ga., John (Tracy) Niles of Baraboo, Robert (Erin) Niles of East Bristol, and Beverly (Jason) Terry of Baraboo; three grandsons, Matthew Powell of Dawsonville, Ga., Drake and Garrett Niles of Baraboo; two step-sons, Tim Frank of Baraboo and Todd (Gloria) Frank of Oceanside, Calif.; step-grandson, Jeremy (Doris) Frank of Seattle, Wash., and the mother of his children, Patricia Frank. Phil is further survived by his siblings, Steven (Helen) Niles, Janice (Jerry) Ward, Christine (Ken) Wilder, Catherine Dreifke, Barbara Smith, Paula (Tom) Blake, John “Jack” Niles, Judith Sutton and Martha Harding; brother-in-law, who has been like a brother to Phil, Daniel (Ruth) Hiller of Baraboo; and many nieces; nephews; other relatives; and a long time close friend, Bruce Boyd of Baraboo. In addition to his parents, Phil was preceded in death by two brothers, Gordon and David Niles; brother-in-laws, Clyde Sutton and Robert Dreifke. Memorial services will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, April 29, 2014 at St. Paul’s Lutheran Church, 727 8th St., in Baraboo, with Pastor Karen Hofstad officiating. Visitation will be at the church on Tuesday from 9:30 a.m. until time of service. Private inurnment will take place in Walnut Hill Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials in honor of Phil may be given to the family. The Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, is assisting the family with arrangements. The family would like to thank the staff at St. Clare Hospice House for the wonderful care given to Phil and his family.

item.title: Mark Allen Kleefisch
item.content:encoded:
Mark Allen Kleefisch, 52, of Baraboo, passed away on Thursday, Feb. 27, 2014 at his residence. Mark was born on June 8, 1961 in Baraboo, the son of Arthur J. and Loretta F. (Weins) Kleefisch. He attended St. Joseph Catholic Grade School and graduated from Baraboo High School in 1980. Mark attended MATC and served two years in the United States Army. He was last employed by the Pizza Pub restaurant in Wisconsin Dells. In his spare time, Mark enjoyed listening to rock music, playing guitar and going to concerts. Survivors include his three brothers, Joseph Kleefisch of Milwaukee, Stephen Kleefisch of Platteville, and David (Norma) Kleefisch of Prescott Valley, Ariz.; and other family and friends. Mark was preceded in death by his parents. A Memorial service will be held at 11 a.m. on Friday, April 25, 2014 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, with Deacon Tom Hale officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home on Friday from 10 a.m. until time of service. Inurnment will take place in St. Joseph Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials in honor of Mark may be given to St. Joseph Catholic Church in Baraboo.

item.title: Terry J. Fisher
item.content:encoded:
Terry “P.I.” J. Fisher, 58, of Baraboo, passed away on Sunday, March 2, 2014 due to injuries from an automobile accident. Terry was born on July 19, 1955 in Janesville, the son of Eugene and Carol (Zantow) Fisher. On Dec. 8, 1974 he was united in marriage to Joyce Hamilton in Baraboo. She preceded him in death on Aug. 31, 2013. Terry had been employed at the Rock Springs Quarry located in Rock Springs for 30 years. His free time was filled with woodworking, bee keeping, hunting, fishing, gardening and family life. Survivors include his parents, Carol Christian of Reedsburg and Eugene Fisher of Sauk City; three children, Kurt (Kerry) Fisher of Wisconsin Dells, Emily (Matthew) Hendricks of Marshall, Damon Fisher of Mead, Colo.; seven grandchildren, Jenna, Justin, Bailey, Boone, Kennedy, Beckett, and Eve; a sister, Cheryl (Dan) Vehling of Sauk City; a stepdaughter, Angela (Carey) Herring of Belleville; and her children, Alexis, Haven, Kylie and Piper; and many other relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by his wife, Joyce; and his grandparents. Memorial services will be held at 12 p.m. noon on Saturday, March 8, 2014 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, with Pastor David Hutchens officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home on Saturday from 9:30 am until time of service. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the family.

item.title: Edward Scott Hutchings
item.content:encoded:
Wisconsin Dells - Edward Scott Hutchings, 63, of Wisconsin Dells, passed away on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2014. Scott, as everyone called him, was born on Feb. 21, 1950 in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, the son of Edward A. and Lyla M. Hutchings. He came to La Crosse with his family in 1956 and graduated from Central High School in 1968. He continued his education at UW La Crosse and Western Wisconsin Tech. His early jobs in La Crosse were teaching organ lessons at Leithhold Music. In 1970, Scott became the head of the color film processing department at WKBT-TV, where he also served as video camera man in the news department when the station went to video tape. When the station changed ownership, Scott then started his own home-improvement business, and later was a partner to a West Salem Restaurant. In 2000, he moved to Wisconsin Dells where he then became part of the family owned private school, Madison Media Institute, from which he retired in 2007. In his spare time, Scott loved cooking, gardening, fishing and working with tools. Survivors include his parents, Edward A. and Lyla M. Hutchings of Lake Delton; a son, Brian (Jessica) Hutchings of Milwaukee; a sister, Shelley R. (Jeff) Hertz of Wausau; two brothers, Steven W. (Julia) Hutchings of Deforest, and Christopher K. (Anna) Hutchings of Marco Island, Fla. He was preceded in death by his maternal and paternal grandparents. Private Memorial services will be held at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo. Memorials in memory of Scott may be given to the Sauk County Humane Society.

<]]>

item.title: Edith J. Lee
item.content:encoded:
Edith J. Lee, 95, of Baraboo, passed away on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2014 at St. Clare Hospital in Baraboo. Edith was born on July 29 1918, in Baraboo, the daughter of Ren and Effie (Bartlett) Loomis. On June 1, 1933 she was united in marriage to Kenneth Dalton Lee. He preceded her in death on Oct. 3, 1997. Edith was a homemaker most of her life and took great joy in raising her nine children. She was a very outgoing sociable person and enjoyed visiting with family and friends. Survivors include eight children, Ronald (Mary Anne) Lee of Lake Delton, Robert (Nancy) Lee of Bushnell, Fla., Richard (Ruth) Lee of Rockford, Ill., Jerry (Sharron) Lee of Tom Bean, Texas, Gail Dobratz, Hank (Pat) Lee, Linda Liebhaber, and John (Melinda) Lee, all of Baraboo; 24 grandchildren; 44 great grandchildren; 24 great-great grandchildren; a sister, Ruby Mason of Baraboo; and many nieces, nephews, other relatives and friends. In addition to her parents and husband, Edith was preceded in death by a daughter, Janice Lee; two grandsons, Patrick Lee and Troy Liebhaber; a great grandson, Ben Lee; two son-in-laws, Richard Dobratz and Frederick Liebhaber; three sisters; and one brother. Funeral services will be held at 12 p.m. noon on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2014 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, with Pastor Derick Bacon and Pastor Bill Haskins co-officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home on Tuesday from 10 a.m. until time of service. Interment will take place in Walnut Hill Cemetery in Baraboo.

<]]>

item.title: Antonio Morales
item.content:encoded:
La Valle – Antonio Morales, 79, of La Valle, passed away on Monday, Feb. 3, 2014 at St. Mary’s hospital in Madison. Antonio was born on October 13, 1934 in San Antonio, Texas, the son of Antonio and Maria (Alcozer) Morales Sr.. He was an over-the-road truck driver for over 50 years and drove for several trucking companies including D&T Trucking in St. Paul, Minn., and Heding Transport in Union Center. In 1952 he married Genevieve Rameriz and from this marriage he had 8 children. After a divorce, he then married Lettie Butcher on Aug. 24, 1985 in La Valle. From this marriage they had two children. Antonio was a loving husband, father, and grandfather who enjoyed his family. In his spare time, he enjoyed gardening and fishing. Survivors include his wife of 28 years, Lettie, and their two children, Brent and Michael Morales of Baraboo; his children from his first marriage, Antonio (Sheryle) Morales, of Bricelyn, Minn., Angie Budde of Nevis, Minn., Mary Helen Johnson of Owatonna, Minn., David (Melinda) Morales of Jordan, Minn., Michael (Lidia) Morales of Rosemount, Minn., Patricia Chapman of Princeton, Minn., Rebecca (Douglas) Busho of Rosemount, Minn.; three step-children, Kathy Tanner of Fresno, Calif., Debbie (Bill) Watts of Reedsburg, Jim Tanner of Chloe, W. Va.; 27 grandchildren; 14 great-grandchildren; two brothers, Goyo (Lorraine) Morales and Marty (Karen) Morales of Minn.; three sisters, Adella Morris of Lynnwood, Wash., Susie (John) Clancy of Mesa, Ariz., and Bebe (Craig) Stangland of Sioux Falls, S.D.; a special niece and nephew, Patricia and John Baldwin of Charleston, W. Va.; and other relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by his parents; and a son, Hector; two brothers, Joe and Luther; and one sister, Anita Rios. Funeral services will be held at 3 p.m. on Saturday, Feb. 8, 2014 at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo, with Deacon Tom Hale officiating. Visitation will be at the funeral home on Saturday, from 1 p.m. until time of services.

<]]>

item.title: Maureen Teelin
item.content:encoded:
Maureen Teelin of Baraboo, passed away suddenly on Monday Feb. 3, 2014 due to a brain aneurism. She is with her God and those she loved who passed before her. Maureen was a graduate from Baraboo schools and earned her Bachelor of Arts degree in archeology and geography at U.W. La Crosse. Many lives were touched by Maureen in so many ways. Caring, loving and kind are just a few words that describe the very heart and soul of her. Even in death she was “giving.” Maureen was an organ donor so others may live. She is survived by her parents, Terry and Una Teelin; her brother, Tom (Joy) Teelin; sisters, Kelly Teelin and Laura (Doug) Baragar; her companion, Matthew Gumz; and many aunts, uncles, numerous cousins (here in the USA and Ireland), and her many dear friends. She will be sorely missed. She was preceded in death by her maternal and paternal grandparents. Private family services will be held at the Rago-Baldwin Funeral Home, 520 East St., in Baraboo. In lieu of flowers, donations in Maureen’s memory may be made to the UW Health Transplant or Organ Donation program at UW Health.org. May God hold you in the palm of his hand until we meet again!

<]]>
